pros: Nice people for work with
cons: Not many monies left for wife

pros: Advancement opportunities, great at developing skills, great place to learn a skill and grow your resume, or grow with the company.
cons: Understaffing issues negatively affects all parts of their business. However, Walmart has increased their minimum hourly rate with hopes to attract more committed employees, and retain better employees.

review: Big enough to get lost or hide out in.
pros: Size and scope of the enterprise means that whatever your niche is, there is likely a team or product that wants your specialization. Living near the corporate headquarters is definitely a selling point. Northwest Arkansas was amazing when I first started and has only kept getting better.
cons: It's a retailer not an IT company. It's got that baked into its bones and it shows sometimes with the decision/procurement process. Tech debt is pretty high in some areas and often it won't be addressed due to penny wise, pound foolish thinking. Northwest Arkansas and by proxy the Bentonville campus is liberal for the South but conservative for the tech industry standards. Sometimes people are waaaaayyyyy out of step with that reality and either want the Good Old Boy days to come back or can't understand why their deeply held views are labelled as being Social Justice Warrior-esque.

review: served my time in Wally World
pros:
Your typical soulless grind to earn Walmart another dollar of off my back. We're expendable, as I was told by a female Troll of a supervisor. Fantastic way to demonstrate how we are not valued as human beings or even respected out of decency.

 The job paid decently for the infamously cheap employer area and the hours were plentiful, albeit only because i had open availability. The insurance and benefits were terrible from what i heard, so i did not bother to sign up for any when my 6 months came up. The supervisors were nice and respectable, so that was a plus. Most of the coworkers were fine people, with the exception of one dwarf.

Suffice to say i did not do well in my role and was fired eventually, but i did not despair but rejoice as I was once more free and i laid my head down with a satisfied smile.
cons: Start of shift and the dawn of the next day.

review: Change is the only constant thing at Walmart
pros: Endless opportunities for growth and promotions or movements into new areas of the business that you will gain experience and further leverage to know the business and be successful. Bonus payout tied to performance.
cons: Different orgs have different priorities and moving from one to another (such as operations to HR/Global people) you will find that topics in the office your former team would consider marginal and petty are actively embraced to enable associates who are insubordinate and require you earn their respect when you come in at a leadership level…in operations the associates are taught to act with urgency and move forward and take the guidance of leadership, regardless of how new they are to your team or not.

pros: There’s job security in the sense that retail is an industry that won’t be going anywhere for the foreseeable future. If you’re young the pay is okay.
cons: Pay is static through positions middle management like team leads. It’s not based on skill or how well you do, everyone gets paid pretty much the same unless you work on food side. Company does not pay holiday pay, you have to use your own PTO if you’d like to be paid the two days of the year the stores are closed ( thanksgiving and Christmas). The scheduling across all positions is much less than flexible than in the past. Team leads pretty much run the store, and if you close the store, it very well ends up as you running half of the store for $19/HR, which is just chump change for doing a job that used to pay 50-60k in salary. Overall not worth it.

pros: Not working hard gets you rewarded. Training is only used in testing not actual daily performance. If you go to jail because of something you did at this job you are welcomed back.
cons: All ways do what they tell you or get voted off the island so to speak. It's takes one of your  piers 1 manager, 1 upper management to comment write you up. to get rid of you if they find a reason. Or simply clock in and out wrong on time clock, seconds count too. This sets you up to get fired quickly.For example if a associate stabbed some one with a knife and  goes to jail you'll get rehired back. Clock in and out wrong they won't ever hire you back again. This was a actual Instance that occurred while working there. You may be asked to do 5 different jobs none which you were hired for. No manager will back you up or fix anything you have a problem with. I went in a happy angel walked out soulless demon who hates people. But this is what Wal-Mart does to you and type of people who shop there contribute. Only leaving will you become a happy person again. Give Wal-Mart-5 stars for so many different reasons.

pros:
I’ll be forever grateful they hire people over 60. I couldn’t get a response from other local companies despite an excellent recent employment record. 

 The hourly crew on my shift was great, funny and supportive, as long as you weren’t a slacker.

Every week we got free bakery goods in the break room.
cons:
Other than that, it could be a nightmare. The work was extremely physical. I expected that but not the unsafe conditions. Example: When unloading delivery trucks, we were often doing unsupported heavy lifting above our heads. And there were always trip hazards around our feet. 

The HVAC system in the back died and it took them 2 weeks (Fla in summer) before they brought us fans. I had to change into dry clothes on my lunch break. BTW, employees use the public restrooms. There aren’t any behind the scenes. 

Training was too generic, nothing specific to the job. I wasn’t even given a box cutter the first day I was stocking on the floor! I saw that happen to many other newbies. We were supposed to make marks on boxes we didn’t finish but weren’t provided markers. 

Pay was better than fast food, $11, but unfair considering all the job entailed.

pros:
*Reasonable Current Management
*Friendly but Professional Management
*Pleasant coworkers for the moment.
Can trust Dave and Tom, their performance is so exceptional that we all gain bonuses and benefits, and they advocate for our needs heavily.
cons:
Extremely rude, unreasonable, and hostile customers, making you have to be skeptical of their intentions even with something as benign as getting a car for them when you're not supposed to leave your post due to position.
Coworkers rarely know what their job entails, so whoever steps in to cover Self Checkout rarely knows that they need to watch the customer, not check them out at the front desk,which let's people easily steal.
Corporate is extremely disconnected from what it's like and what's needed to actually keep the store running and back backwards policies and requirementsthat run quality to the ground, or don't consider lack of staffing or minimal staffing situations.

pros: I enjoy using the mass email blast to remind my clients about promotions, discounts, etc. i think it's definitely worth the monthly spend! it keeps my day-to-day business steady and organized.
cons: When an appointment is upcharged during service , the amount due is reverted back to the original booking causing the business to lose money.

pros: Nice people for work with
cons: Not many monies left for wife

pros: Advancement opportunities, great at developing skills, great place to learn a skill and grow your resume, or grow with the company.
cons: Understaffing issues negatively affects all parts of their business. However, Walmart has increased their minimum hourly rate with hopes to attract more committed employees, and retain better employees.

cons: When an appointment is upcharged during service , the amount due is reverted back to the original booking causing the business to lose money.

pros:
Able to meet some interesting characters.
Free Schooling benefits for pt and ft employees through the Live Better U! education program.
Flexible with scheduling my days off.
cons:
Leadership can be difficult to work for at times.
Easy to get "lost in the crowd" with so many employees.
Quite a bit of rules and regulations that are fireable offenses.

pros:
Decent money
Excellent benefits
Growth opportunities
Flexible schedule
cons:
Mixed leadership
General public 
Negative company perception

review: Not the most motivated place to work
pros:
Good benefits
Co-workers become family
Good resources on the company portal
Continuing education resources
There's a great push on Diversity and Inclusion in the Metro areas
cons:
Aggressive company to rank among the retail work
Associates pay isn't the best 
Upper management has a lack of compassion towards associates and/or lower management
No work/life balance once you have reached salary position
Not a lot of talent that gets promoted
Always playing catch up and never able to teach and train

pros: When i first started, i liked working for walmart. they are a great place to work with good pay for a starting job or some people make a career out of it. they also will assist in paying to help further your education which i think is great.
cons:
some of the downsides i found over my almost 6 years is the community. each store is way different than the rest which can be good but how some stores do things and manage situations is different from other stores. at the time that im writing this, there is a lot of logistical problems going on. so a problem is that customers would come in expecting items to be there and they arent. this has become a nightmare for associates. 

Another big con i have found is the management training. salaried management goes through the same training and is pretty universal. the lack of training i have found is in the team leads. to me it seemed like there was little leadership training and more task delegation training to fit that boss or manager role and not the "team leader" role.

review: Job is not worth the headache
pros:
- the money is some of the best in this city for a job with no experience required
- it is simple to learn
- work never really changes, always the same. Sometimes there is more to stock, sometimes less
cons:
- management does not work well with associates and themselves (There is no communication and suggestions by associates to management for improving processes will be ignored)
- High expectations for stocking times despite not having enough staff/ not scheduling enough staff
- Management consistently lies and corporate policy is either disregarded or not followed
- they discourage you from using the time off you have EARNED and threaten reprimanding you if you leave early by using this time in the guise of "productivity".

review: a racist company to work for!
pros: overall, has some great benefits!
cons: management and departments forced to good employees!

pros: Easy Money. Relaxed atmosphere. Good Exercise. Hour Lunch and 2, 15min, breaks. Nice Managers. Helpful Co-Workers. No Customers for most of the night so unbothered work.
cons: On feet all night, lifting, bending, squatting, and climbing. Some naggy coworkers

review: Can get overwhelming at times but decent pay
pros:
$14 an hour starting pay.
Depending on what role they have you some are easier than others. 
- Dispensing: Bring the order out to the customer.
- Staging: You help organize the location of customers' orders for the dispensers.
- Picking: You go out throughout the store and pick the customer's orders. 

Our store is not always running at full capacity and we have to shut down because we simply do not have enough people. 

There really aren't that many pros other than $14 an hr.
cons:
Generally the whole business strucutre in terms of managemnt/leadership.
Sometimes impolite customers but Online Pickup and Delivery (OPD) customers are generally better than the sales floor customers.

Dispensing can and will get tiring, sometimes it feels like people be ordering the whole store. 9/10 times a customer's item in an order will be substituted. Our job is 100% reliant on technology, if there are system shut downs it's gonna be a long day.

Team leads are constantly nagging you to stay busy. Sometimes making you do busywork. 

getting pulled to do stocking or do front-end returns.

Working at Walmart in general has a high turnover. I don't recommend working for Walmart for a long time. No one ever stays long enough to get good at what they do.

pros: Good pay for managers, good 401(k) match, a good bonus if you work in a good profitable store. A good company to invest money in but I wouldn’t recommend working there if you’re looking for a long-term job life time job. I only had 2 good store managers in my 20 year career.
cons:
District manages and up can be pleasant but some are real unpleasant. It’s the lucky if you work for a decent manager and they either help creat a good working atmosphere or make a hostile negative working environment.
Company has very high turnover. Most stores turn over were 80-120 percent. If you didn’t go over that goal then you were doing good. I think this speaks for itself.

review: Good job to start in automotive but not the best
pros: Basically the reason why you'd have this job is because you're either down low, or want the benefits. Free education (not actually any good universities except for arizona state, but not that many good programs. Somewhat okay healthcare, if you're military this job is great if you're going to college due to military differential pay.
cons: Customers absolutely suck. I'm not a patient person and dealing with customers who read one thing on the internet are insufferable and have no idea how businesses work and try to undermine my expertise (i'm also a blackhawk mechanic in the military) if you are really good at your job you will be able to get promotions fast, but that comes with practically living at the store especially if you are understaffed like every other ACC

review: Decent job if you have good supervisors
pros: Walmart pays better than a lot of retail jobs and the store I work at is clean. My supervisors are kind to me and that makes a big difference.
cons: Making the apparel section not a mess every day gets tiring and frustrating. Many customers have no respect for the store and the merchandise, leaving things all over the floor. Depending on who the supervisors are, you may get a lot of or no appreciation. Some of them are kind and some are very unkind.

pros: Plant care and outdoor work. You are kept busy and get to work multiple tasks. I had a lot of fun working here and the work was fulfilling.
cons: It is seasonal and you will have to work in other places in the store during fall and winter. But this also has its benefits. Heavy lifting (although I enjoyed the manual labor of the job, most do not). $.

pros: I loved working at Walmart it was awesome great working environment amazing people to work with until it came to the management
cons: Management sucked all they cared about was them and if they were able to be at home with there family didn’t give a crap about you and yours

review: Has its good days and bad
pros: Good teamwork, easy work, good place to make friends if you’re social, you can also keep to yourself shopping all day if you aren’t that social, good diversity
cons: Gave us a raise but took away our bonuses so it barely made a difference, things constantly changing when it’s not for the better, dispensing in the rain/heat with no cover and not enough help is agonizing, penalties for our department if the shelves aren’t stocked correctly, customers can easily scam us and get away with it. It’s just very easy but if it was any harder of a job i would quit.

review: Take the good with the bad
pros: You can really find community within your department, sometimes also with management as an associate. There really is someone for everyone to get along to. Pretty good for long term work.
cons: The pay for some departments is really unbalanced. Some people work the hardest and get paid the least, and thats often a problem. You really really have to be involved in your own progress, you wont receive feedback unless you hunt down your manager, and even then they almost never have anything productive for you to work on. As such it's harder to get promoted if you dont know what you're doing wrong. The hours are inconsistent most of the time, especially for upper management. High expectations but zero accountability for the lack of help you receive

pros: You can work as many hours as you want, shifts go by quickly because you can stay busy, lots of variety in duties and helping customers is always interesting. Great opportunity to become close with co-workers.
cons: All of the above are dependent on local management... majority of those who quit from my store say it is management. They will probably schedule you maximum hours and may try to schedule outside of availability. Punishment by "points" for calling in, 6 points within certain time frame means you get fired. No holiday pay, double points for calling in on these days. Time-off requests may be denied, even using PTO.

pros: Full time employee-401k, health/dental benefits, PTO, Stocks (matched 6% for every $1
cons: Nothing I've seen so far has been negative.

pros: I loved working with people as management. This position is very high-paced (I’d typically walk roughly 9 miles a day) and also very rewarding to develop associates to achieve a non-stop increase of companies expectations. The company offers a lot of opportunities, provided the motivation to grow is proven by dedication.
cons: It only takes one senior level management to tarnish an other-wise respectable image. Vice Presidents, Regional Managers and other senior leadership are far too busy to actually be leaders and allow they’re subordinates to operate as they please. Claiming plausible deniability actually still works out for them. The term leadership is disgustingly misinterpreted, the “open door” policy is a joke and just like the rest of all giant corporations, they genuinely do not care about the little people whom they rely on and with no thought of morality will throw you away in a heartbeat. It doesn’t matter how much extra you did for them or how much time you spent away from your aging children to be a “team player”. At the end of the day, we’re all replaceable and loyalty, compassion and fair treatment are merely power words used to make us feel like a member of a family.

review: Each location has it's own attributes, I happen to be in a great location!
pros: Associates are one big family, who were always willing to assist when needed.
cons: Network infrastructure both within the store and on the network overall could use some upgrades. WIFI signal near the outer walls could use boosting, as well as network processing times when querying seemed to lack even during off-peak times.

pros: Good pay, Education help, and more
cons: Not really anything other than tedeus tasks but its alright

pros: As long as you got some friends and a decent work schedule that doesn’t stray into different times during the day, you should be good. A pro tip would be to stretch everything in your body, especially if you’re new. It may seem like a lot to do at first, but like everything in life you gotta go through hardships to be grateful for the present. If you didn’t get that, it means everybody struggles at some point but everyday is a step forward from where you were yesterday.
cons: If anything, just make sure you have a lot of patience and knowledge to deal with customers and people in general. Also, make sure to always ask for help from others.

pros: Flexible hours, easy work, friendly environment
cons: long hours at times, poor management

pros: There are honestly no pros for working for this business. The cons outweighed the pros being part time imo.
cons: There are so many that I can't even imagine speaking on them because listing the reasons will drain the life out of you. The business sucks please just trust me lol.

pros: Pharmacy software is user-friendly and there are many safeguards to prevent errors throughout the process of filling a prescription. There is typically more coverage and less focus on metrics than other retail pharmacies.
cons: Pharmacy software is slow and bulky. Walmart uses Facts & Comparisons for drug information, which is one of the worst available to pharmacists. The company's attempt at inventory automation made the situation worse.

review: Not a shabby job for work experience and development
pros:
* Fair PTO & PPTO
* Opportunities to advance are there for exceptional workers
* Scheduling on the app was a solid move
cons:
* Some days overloaded with responsibility (to the point where you are set up to fail honestly)
* While PPTO is no problem (albeit some stern talking from HR) almost impossible to use PTO any less than a month and a half
* Petty drama and office politics that are neigh impossible to escape

pros: Well I guess the pay was decent and I met some really amazing customers who really appreciate your work
cons: Everything from the discrimination to the favoritism to the retaliation as well as slander and just plain hostile gross work environments and those who try to follow Walmart policy and health codes the way that customers hope that they would get fired for unjust false reasoning and when you report it to home office home office does not give you a second chance doesn't even look into it they take the managers word for it and that's it even if you have recordings documents pictures witnesses and police reports

pros: Work from home, they provide you with all the equipment you need to get the job done and it’s all top notch electronics, there’s never really any issues with their stuff or their network. Even though you’re working remote you still have instant access to leadership, tech support and peers.
cons: They put a lot of emphasis on having built a solid foundation, anchored by four core values that they fail to uphold. Companies don’t have to have “core values” to be successful so I find it very shameful that they went out of their way to conjure up such a facade, just to run it through the mud.

review: Both what I thought and not what I thought.....
pros: The people I work with and the 10% discount card
cons: The "task times" given to complete stocking shelves. Make you park nearly as far away as possible. The paperwork received at orientation states that WalMart understands that you can't be expected to be available to work 24/7, 365. But if and when you do call in or have to leave early, points are given to you against attendance. At 4.5 points, they start looking to replace you. At 5 points---you are gone.

pros:
Good culture,PT0,401K,
Employee reviews are generally of very good quality, provide complementary views and give a good picture of the organization. All SaaS, easy to use, fast, immediate results.
cons: There are times where not all companies have enough information and the reviews on some are very old and can be misleading.

pros: The pay was decent for a part-time, entry-level position. Note: the online order fulfillment positions pay more than the floor associate positions. I found the culture at my store to be surprisingly chill and supportive. I found myself regretting that I had to quit, because I enjoyed the people and the environment.
cons: The only downside I can report is the physicality of the work. Then again, I'm no spring chicken. For a young person working through school or looking for a career foothold in a stable company, I think this is a great opportunity. But if you're middle-aged with some physical issues, I would exercise caution. There's lots of repetitive, moderately heavy lifting (40-packs of bottled water seemed to be the most common offender here) which is fine if you use good lifting techniques. --Lift with your legs--keep your back straight-- But when you are trying to load heavy products into a customer's junky back seat, you may find yourself compromising your back just to get the job done. Also, there are times that are chaotically busy. The trick is not to lose your cool, no matter how frazzled you feel.

pros: Always something to do . No idleness
cons: Flexibility demand is high so inflexibility when comes to scheduling.

pros: Lunch break 30 min. Great 401 k match. Most help tech wise than any other retail pharmacy
cons: Walmart has the most rules and regulations to follow out of any retail pharmacy. You must follow every sop procedure

review: It's hard to recommend, but it could be worse I guess...
pros:
People are typically nice and polite. I've met some amazing people. I loved the culture of servant leadership from the top. 
Can get exposed to a lot of different subjects/industries.
Some areas have great teams and work cultures.
Doug, the CEO, seems really great and can help employees feel bought into the mission. 
Does some great Corporate Responsibility and Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion work.
cons:
LOTS of layoffs. I had my roles eliminated 3 times in 7 years. 
Employee experience varies widely. Some teams are great, some are bad. Onboarding as an external candidate is really hard, especially because it's so big. 
Getting promoted within the company can be really challenging. I had a terrible time in every role , even when I was really successful in role. 
Plays favorites. A select few are very successful and the rest of overworked and undervalued. 
They also blatantly try to keep your wages as low as possible. 
I never felt valued for my contributions or work. 
Treats their employees like cogs in a machine. 
Performance evaluations are biased, unhelpful, and frustrating. 
Culture is so operations and action focused that strategy can go out the window. Lots of people spend most of their capacity on short term, high stress, crisis problem solving. 
So fast paced and understaffed that every job is designed to be 1.5-2 jobs. Achieving anything and being recognized for your contributions is really hard.
Workaholic culture. It's better then it used to be but still high stress.

pros: My experience working for Walmart great. I enjoyed the work that I performed, most of my coworkers, my supervisor and the assistant manager over our department. I felt the benefits for the job that I held was appropriate and should be expected. Walmart has many programs for employees that are trying to better themselves if an employee only apply themselves.
cons: Pay and benefits fit the positions. I don't know why a person would expect more from unskilled jobs though.

pros: Good hours and nobody is on top of you to get work done
cons: Managers expect too much of new employees

pros: Pay is good and the shift is good and management is good
cons: U have to be in shape

pros: Consistent schedules and good pay, if your store dose well you can get a nice bonus every qurter (every 3 months) management in my current store is very friendly
cons: In most stores there is little to no communication with management, unrealistic expectations and if you ever step up in management your position may get deleted at any time, so there is little to no job security,

pros: Straightforward, typical, fairly predictable, and mostly friendly co-workers
cons: Managers not on the same page, seasoned co-workers see their way as the best way

pros: Rewarding. Seeing project from start to finish is really gratifying. Teaming with the Stores to complete a project.
cons: Working nights takes some getting use to.

pros: Flexible hours and friendly working environment
cons: Rude customers and dirty store

pros: Flexible hours and friendly working environment
cons: Rude customers and dirty store

pros: Gave u your assignment and let you be
cons: The pay for night stalker

pros: Choose your own hours, relatively high pay
cons: A lot of physical activity

pros:
The company description section of your business plan is typically the second section, coming after the executive summary.1﻿ The company description outlines vital details about your company, such as where you are located, how large the company is, what you do, and what you hope to accomplish.2﻿


The company description of your business plan describes the vision and direction of the company so potential lenders and partners can develop an accurate impression about who you are.3﻿


What to Include
The exact elements included in your company description can vary, but some elements are more common than others and most likely should be part of the section:

Company name: The official name of yo
cons:
That’s right, company stories are not just for tech start-ups. Every business, no matter how big or small, needs to tell a story on their website. It’s just another step towards building a better website for your small business.
Having a story to share on your website is a great way to attract new customers. Remember that people choose to hire professionals that 1) They like, 2) they trust, and 3) they feel like they know. The same holds true for businesses – we’re people after all.

Writing an effective description for your small business is easier than you think.

We’ll show you how to write an effective business description using the power of storytelling. Follow our simple guide to create your own small business description in less than 20 minutes.

pros: This job is a great entry into the world of retail. You build retail and people skills over time and the tools they give you are very helpful. They offer about 10 different schools and a lot of different career paths.

I have no major cons about Walmart.

pros: Benefits and pay can be very great all around. The distribution center I transferred from was a great facility. The % quotas can seem extreme at first, but as you work for the dc longer they seem more fair. Especially as a order filler.
cons:
Safety at some locations is a low priority, especially at retail side.
Manager expectations can be extreme and unclear. They only have a broad task time that doesn't acount for how fast you actually work. With por management this can be a problem for new hires. I had a write up for production in my first month of working here with out a clear explanation. 
I had no problem with production at my dc job and was able to average 50 to 70% above the 100% expectation. Wich is much harder to do than stock shelves.
If you work at Walmart it can be a gamble of whether management will be fair with you.

pros: Good company culture and programs for hourly associates.

pros: I liked the environment of my co workers.

review: Walmart is the best pharmacy, but there is never enough help
pros: Walmart's benefits are pretty great.
cons: Upper management has no clue how much workload we have, and tries to push on more and more without hiring more help. Even if we have our backs against the wall, OT is never allowed for tech except in very rare circumstances. You will be pulled in every direction from the moment the day starts until it ends. I will say that it is better than working at CVS or Walgreens, but that's not saying much.

pros: Co workers are really great. Very friendly and helpful to each other.
cons:
Management is very unorganized and rude. They don’t schedule enough employees to cover their departments in order to keep their bonuses and expect the work to be done, and they sweat you over getting it done, even though they know they didn’t schedule enough people.

The lunch room is dirty and also doesn’t accommodate the amount of people who need a place to eat their lunch.

They make employees feel like they could lose their job at a moment’s notice over petty things. I have seen good, hard working people worked to the point of exhaustion and made to feel like they didn’t do enough.

My supervisor spoke Spanish and English, but would mostly speak Spanish. She told me that if I wanted her to speak to me, I needed to learn to speak Spanish.

When I left, they asked me to stay because I’m a good worker. NOPE. I deserve a better environment than that.

I will never work for Walmart again and I don’t recommend it.

review: You're Gunna Go Far, Kid (at Walmart!)
pros: I was given achievable goals and an adequate amount of time to reach them. In turn, I was able to challenge myself to go beyond what was expected. I was never pushed to do more than I could manage. This made me confident in myself and my work. At Walmart, I felt that no matter how small my "cog in the machine" was my work mattered just as much as the head of the establishment.
cons: As a member of the Modular Team, our primary role was to make changes. In some instances, it was neccessary for us to have to think on our feet, making adjustments to prior plans. I found the challenge fun and rewarding although at times, the sudden pressure of completing an additional high priority task nearing the end of a shift could really throw a wrench in the perfectly timed task already in progress. It would change a previously fun challenge into a stressed situation. I've seen where is hurt the progress and morale of the team.

They don’t provide necessary equipment, and expect areas to be perfectly maintained even when staffed at 40% (or lower!) at one point I had a one person ‘team’ (instead of the 6-9 I should have) and yet I was still expected to perform as of fully staffed. Training is negligible and laughable, even higher ups and salaried don’t know proper policy, and they refuse to listen to subordinates, often treating them as lesser.

review: It’s All a Game… Just Play It Well
pros: If you make friends easily and are fine with being cross-trained, it’s a great place to work. Their 401k plans and disability insurance are great. The people make the company what it is and you will meet some amazing people here. For short-term or college students, this is a great place to work. I’ve met some of my best friends here and the environment is so much fun when your coworkers are your friends.
cons: If you don’t play into the politics or the system of the store, you’re gonna get screwed. There is a lot of favoritism and lots of people don’f like playing by the book. Depending on the area (specifically service areas like OGP or Automotive), you will get crumby hours to fit the needs of the department and if you close, you’re likely going to be one of the few closers who do it well or enjoy doing it. Long-term, I would not stick here unless you’re in a higher-up position or competitive.

pros: Half decent money, but they did a lot of shady stuff in the last ten years so no one is making what they should be making.
cons: *Constantly* changing work policies and methods from one year to the next. Everything new in 2020/2021 has been a disaster so far. Always short handed, supervisors getting laid off and having their pay removed because their raises were higher than the new cap for the lower position they were forced into. New phones they give out to associates still don't even work right. Missing key programs on 'new' system from 2015. Smart system that was supposed to be 100% gone by 2015, still around because the home office wont hire good programmers to make appropriate apps for remaining old systems. Regular associates being forced to take on duties that were once supervisor only. Have been told that associates are now basically department managers. Associates now forced to cover up to 4 departments at once instead of just one. Removed many supervisor positions to consolidate payroll. Now Team leads must cover multiple departments instead of just one. Cost cutting to the extreme, company no longer cares about associates who are not interested in climbing the crooked ladder. Quarterly Bonuses were removed and replaced with an hourly raise that did not equal even 50% of the average bonus. Used to get $300 average quarterly bonus for a regular associate. replacement raise equals to less than $150 per quarter. Corporate have replaced carrot with stick. Were given PPTO to shield from tardy points, only to have it eat into regular PTO and have rates adjusted so associates get less total PPTO&PTO overall now.

From what I hear, it was a lot more easier to hire in more people before Sam died.

pros: Wal-mart has unbelievable support benefits insurance the list goes on and on. If you want to work for a company that looks out for you in every good way and not in a negative way, this is where you belong.
cons: The only downside at Walmart it is tough to climb the ladder it takes years of pursuit in a style similar to what a politician might go thru essentially being accepted by every employee as deserving to be promoted. Another words it doesn't happen easily. If you are a hard worker, get ready to be used hard and put up wet. I suggest taking everything you do at a pace because if you are out to impress you had better be prepared to keep that pace because it will become required and expected without any kind of gratification or appreciation for putting forth extra at work. There is not any type of reward system for someone who puts in 110% and doing so will not benefit you. I recommend watching people your first couple of days and paying attention to stay in the mainstream average. You will not get a raise and will not gain for extra hard work ethic and from personal experience let me say that learning this lesson is hard on your motivation once you have. So don't do it. Set a pace you can easily handle and stick to it no matter what and enjoy your job its a cinch.

review: Great role for detail oriented person getting their start in retail.
pros:
1. Although you’re part of a team, you do have plenty of individual assignments if you like to work independently. 
2. Role allows you to set the  foundation of the whole store - you get to set new product categories and updates and learn about [potentially] exciting changes before most people. 
3. The whole store is your domain so be prepared to move from automotive oil one night to frozen dinners the next.
cons:
1. There are times when a mod takes longer than expected and you’re sometimes required to stay and finish after you’re scheduled shift end.
2. Time is of essence and you’re always under time constraints so you can put yourself under constant pressure.
3. Some mods can be outright disgusting when you start taking them apart (be prepared for old chicken wing bones).

pros: They're pretty flexible there, and they pay pretty well for simple work. They're nondiscriminant, at least at my store.
cons: They don't really care about you personally. If you have an issue and don't harass everyone, nothing will change. When I got hired, I was supposed to make 15 an hour, but something happened within the system, and I was hired at 11. I was notified about this at orientation, and that it would be fixed before my shift the next day. A couple of days passed and I noticed that my title hadn't changed, so I went to talk to someone about it, just to get an update. I was told that it was being fixed and to wait a few days. A week passed, and nothing was fixed. When I went to ask about it I was told that it was supposed to be fixed that Saturday which was about five days away. Although I was pleased to finally hear something other than ambiguity, I was very annoyed, especially because I continued to make 11 until the following Saturday; a week after I was promised. I'm not even sure if I'll see the money I had already earned but wasn't given. However, at the end of the day, it was fixed.

review: Only if you're really in need of money.
pros:
-Some of the pros of working there was that you get ppto and you can be paid for not being there and you wouldn't have to worry about points

- The team leads are generally kind and helpful

- Decent pay

- Pretty ok scheduling

- Really nice coworkers

- The work can be easy from time to time depending on the department you mainly work in

- An hour lunch and 2 15 minute paid breaks
cons:
- The coaches do not communicate with each other.

- Terrible structure

- The point system itself.

- When you are hired you are supposed to learn everything in about a week or two, which makes sense but you will not be taught everything and will be written up when they forget to teach you something that you don't know yet and be called slow regardless.

- You are not paid for what you do and will be taken advantage of. There is a team called Cap 2 and the HBA team, in Cap 2 you are only supposed to zone the isles, do top stock, picks, and trucking, returns, and the occasional pallet. In HBA you are mainly to do price changes, clearance reviews, counts, outs, top stock, returns, the occasional pallet, and zoning. The overnighters are to mainly do the pallets. I constantly saw Cap 2 work in ALL of the areas of Walmart working off pallets and doing trucking alongside HBA and even doing what they call "freight swarms".

- You rarely get the equipment needed for your job to actually do your job and make it quicker unless you hide some of your own.

- They don't take into account physical conditions that you may have.

- A miserable energy. Regardless of who I talked to even coaches say how much they hate their job and just being there.

review: No support for parents of NICU patients.
pros: I worked in the deli so I could clock in at the front of the store instead of walking all the way to the back.
cons: When my son was born he was admitted to the NICU. I had to take more time off than allowed with FMLA to take care of his medical needs and I was fired for taking too much time off to do so. Why didn’t I have PTO time? Because I was denied promotion to Full-Time after a one week stay in the hospital four months prior to my son’s birth. I had a brain hemorrhage (high blood pressure forced blood through the walls of a cavernoma adjacent to my brain stem). When I went to talk to HR and ask if I was still eligible to go full time, the assistant manager over my department said “Absolutely not. It’s a reward for employees who work 40 hours without attendance issues.” “I was in the hospital with a brain hemorrhage!” “Well, if you were in the hospital then you weren’t working 40 hours, were you?” This company doesn’t give any concern for the health and well-being of their employees or that of their families.

review: Market treats salary worse than animals

More times than not it will be up to 80 hours weekly. Horrible communication between management, as well as corporate. Systems rarely work, nor are they always secured access. Unrealistic hours given for freight and task flow. Accountability never for other shifts. Ethical and compliance issues are never ending.

pros:
promotional opportunities are plentiful 
Several good benefits including 401k, stock share, etc. 
Compensation for management fair
cons:
Work is life... don't have a family or personal issues as a manager. LOA's frowned on and while obviously never said out loud puts a target on you, and constant pressure to be always available. 
With "app driven" leadership seeing less and less family and personnel time. As you are always connected and can never disconnect. 24 hours/364 (you get Christmas off unless your overnight)

pros: Discount card on your 31st day of employment.
cons: Never enough associates at any location. Unless you are a pet or management is a friend you will likely be overlooked for any type of promotion or advancement. They hire so many teenagers or persons unable and unwilling to learn the English language there is always a language barrier. As a lead you will be blamed for your associates not preforming well. You can call out sick 5 times in a 6 month span. They do not accept Dr. notes or excuses so plan your sickness around your days off. They do not pay for Holidays you will be expected to work all of them. The bonuses that you can acquire depends on if your store is doing well, if it is doing well your bonus will be calculated by the amount of days you have called off in a 4 month period, if you have called off 3 or more times you will not receive a share of that bonus even if you have worked overtime, come in on your off days or basically almost killed yourself getting your area like they want it.

review: The juice is not worth the squeeze. Too much politics & lack of freedom.
pros:
This position can be worked from home now. 
Co-workers are mostly helpful and enthusiastic.
Managers are on the clock trying to be as helpful as possible.
Small perks like discount cards for stores.
cons:
-LOW pay with no chance of a raise even after a year unless you go WAY above and beyond. 
-RIDICULOUS expectations that will determine your schedule (95% on satisfaction from callers, 6.25 minutes to end a call when caller could have several inquiries, they want you to take 7-30 seconds per call)
-You cannot pick your schedule, they only let top performers pick their schedules
- NO VTO or voluntary time off. Their new "VTO policy" only lets you take up to 3-4 days off whether sick or to just take time off. After it's not even disciplinary, just right to termination. 
- HEAVY favouritism. People in the lower ranks can't have time off, while managers take OOT every 2 weeks. 
- Pay holiday pay by taking it out of your PTO hours. Meaning you are getting paid what you already had.
-Upper management such as team leaders and above don't help out.
- To apply to another department, you have to wait 6 months to a year. Even if you quit or are let go.

pros: $0.50 soda in the breakroom
cons:
Inconsistent schedule no one week had the same days or hours 

I was part time but because of the laws in California they would give me 40 hours for 5 weeks then 18 on the 6th week they did this so I would work full time hours but not get any of the benefits 

The store was constantly understaffed so everyone was over worked 

Leadership was lacking to say the least and the store was a revolving door for management at all levels people were either fired demoted or left and each time someone new took the position of assistant manager or manager they changed how the store was ran and things never got better no matter how was I charge

The store had high turnover so add to the unreasonable work training the new employees fell to lower level employees like myself 

And the customer were either neutral and or incredibly rude and acted like they owned you and your jobs depends on you taking it with a smile

pros:
- Loved my co-workers, especially up in the front end. Made my bad days feel much better. The Associates I interacted with were friendly and cool to hang around.

- I wasn't just a cashier; I also worked in different parts of the Front End of the store. Really does toughen you up, but was a great experience.
cons:
- Management could not really work around my school schedule despite me being new; I understand that there is a probation period under which new associates have to be observed, but the Front End manager would not accept my "True Availability" form because of school. I quit as soon as college started so I could my education first. I could not keep working mostly closing shifts over my already-heavy classes.

- It seems that almost 32-36 hour work weeks are considered "part-time". I feel lied to.

review: Bad Wal-Mart Bad Boy Bad Bad!!!!!!
pros: People worked with are great. All in same boat - stuck in a no end job with no room for growth. Overworked and underpaid.
cons:
Expected to do work of Dept Managers without Department Manager pay. Hours are only good during the holidays then they expect you to work yourself to death. 
Don't put in for time off or vacation. It is your Manager who decides if and when you may get time off or not. Even when you put in for a vacation expecting to leave soon and find out you have been scheduled more hours than you usually receive in same amount of time. Dr appointments are no different if you have an appointment and you must request it ahead of schedule don't count on it. 
There is no way to advance at Wal-Mart anymore, hours get cut and cut and cut again with out notice. 
It doesn't matter how hard you work or how much you give they do not care and will just take and take however much you are willing to give without so much as a pat on the back. But, hey, isn't that what your co-workers are for?? Begging you not to quit? Sam Walton would be dearly ashamed at what the company he loved and prided himself on has become. He was all about his employees!!! How times have changed.

pros: Easy work, great managers, and good at organizing

pros: Walmart is a fast friendly job

pros:
They now pay 15.50/ hour stocking overnights in the Findlay, OH area. 
Employees get protective PTO to cover existing posts or future points for missing work.
cons:
The insurance has gone up.
3rd shift is overworked and hiring is sparse. 
You get stuck working the same area every night if you work hard. The lazy workers get all the easy areas and get rewarded with them. 
Don't allow you to move up in the company even when you outwork your own team leads. 
Even if you're over qualified for management positions they most likely won't hire you for them. 
You get to work other people's tasks when you work harder. You never get help when you're a hard worker.
Scheduling vacation time is never approved unless you go and cry to HR. 
They will work you every weekend unless you tell them you can't work Friday's, Saturday's or Sunday's.
You have to work every Holiday!

pros: The Vision Center manager is knowledgeable and makes her work a true craft; great place to get work experience as an ophthalmic technician, optician, salesperson, eye-wear consultant, cashier, etc; no experience necessary (but preferred); you truly feel the difference that you make in people's daily lives; WM employee discount
cons: Scheduling (be prepared to work anywhere from 8am-7pm Mon-Sat and/or 11-4 Sun); overtime is discouraged; WM work-weeks start on Saturdays; when I worked there the pay wasn't enough compensation for the amount of work (to my knowledge there has been a raise)

pros:
The day passes by very quickly.

It's very unlikely for you to get fired, regardless of your performance.
cons:
The work is very hard and breaks your body down significantly if you work in the back room. The trolley things they have you use were designed with handles but the handles didn't end up working out well so you're told not to use them. This means you have to bend over a very large portion of the day and push these trolleys around very close to the ground, rearranging them very often. Picking up heavy baskets and moving them from location a to location b to location c to location d to location e over and over again quickly breaks your back down.
There is no real career development or advancement opportunities in this role and no time to train to do anything other than work in this department.

review: Benefits Are Great if You're Young..
pros: Great benefits.. Currently finishing my Bachelors for FREE (paid 100% by walmart).. I started when they only charged 1$ a day which I wasn't complaining about bc it came out to only about $60 per semester, but now that it is free I'm even happier. PTO is acquired pretty easily.. so I Love that.. Also, You're bound to meet great people, shoppers and associates alike.. In-store and out ofnstore discounts made available to associates.. I really recommend this job for younger people who need cash.. I dont recommend this for a long term career unless you just plan on moving up in the store later..
cons: For the amount of stress cashiers and sales assoc. go through, the pay could be better.. People get promoted and take their little power too far.. People rarely focus on their own work.. And This honestly depends on the store because I loved my previous store, but from my experience in my current store the morale is low and management makes you hate coming to work... I came to my current store due to covid, but planned on transferring back to the one on my University's campus the first chance I got.. when I mentioned this I ended up "coincidentally" getting a coaching (write-up) about two days later for something so small.. However, the year mark of when my write up is scheduled to fall off is coming up soon, so I'll be starting my transfer literally the second it does....

pros: the pay, and with what you have to do it’s still not worth it.
cons:
well in my experience unable to work with my schedule.
the team i had was awful.
management doesn’t care about you, your direct team lead might but the rest of them could care less as long as you are producing food they don’t care if you are short handed.
also don’t look to move up in the company, the current teamleads get first dibs on new team lead positions. even ones who have no experience in the food industry at all then you get stuck training your boss, while you were rejected the position after “careful consideration”

pros: Decent pay but the pay does not outweigh the cons
cons: Management was run in a very teacher's pet and favorites manner. Some may say it's an office politics environment but in a warehouse setting. They claim to add your name to a "list" when you ask to get cross trained on additional equipment and other positions. However it was clear and proven that they were giving the advancement opportunities to their friends or favorites within the company rather than based on performance or the order if the list. Witnessed first hand management telling a very underperforming and unqualified individual that they would be great for management and other opportunities within the company because they were a minority and female. While they should never be discrimination against such individuals giving priority or special privileges over others better suited for such rolls is a very poor in the betterment of the company. The list goes on...

pros: Great place to start your career. There's so much career opportunities in the company of Walmart. Get to know your management team and they are more than happy to teach and train you on how to become a leader. It's not just about working hard, but leading a team. Walmart is shifting to a different direction and expecting a lot from these new "team lead" positions. Team lead's are now having the responsibilities of the assistant manager. That's why the pay range is $20-$30 based on experience. I love the pay because it's more than most retail and Walmart is always changing to become better!
cons: Short staffed due to the pandemic and very difficult to hire.

pros: The insurance is good. I know I make more money than some of my peers. I feel like its job security because so many people shop there. No matter how bad the economy gets, consumers are still going to need to buy groceries so I also feel like its a good choice to stay stable in uncertain times.
cons: Wal-Mart's attendance policy leaves things to be desired. I understand that people shouldn't call in all the time. But I totally disagree with giving someone an unexused absense when they have a doctor's note to prove that they or a family member were actually ill. I have a write up on my record that i was given for missing a total of six days in a twelve month period. Only one of those absenses did not include a doctor's note. Actually the one day I missed that I didn't go to the doctor was due to a sunburn I recieved while I was working on a charity project for guess who...Wal-Mart!

cons: Being expected to do other job duties not suited for (eg. cashiering when hired to do stocking or sales). Must have doctor's statement if unable to do certain jobs. Having rigid schedule for some positions.

pros: There are three pros of working at Walmart. First, Walmart fully pays for my college education. Second, Walmart offers a good 401k plan because Walmart offers a 100% match of up to 6% of your paycheck that is invested in your 401k. Third, walmart offers a 15% match on any Walmart stock purchases.
cons: There are several cons about working at Walmart. First, Walmart does not pay as well as many other major retailers such as Target and Costco, which both pay a minimum of $15 an hour. Second, Walmart takes away your previously earned raises when they bump the base pay up. This year I received my second pay raise, which bumped me from $13.16 to 13.42; however, my pay second pay raise was taken away when the Walmart raised its base pay from $12.90 an hour to $14. I now only make $14.16 an hour, instead of the $14.42 an hour that I should be making, which is unbelievable to me because currently my pay is only $0.16 more than any associate that is now hired in my department. It's unbelievable to me that I have been at Walmart for almost three years and I only make 16 cents more an hour than brand new associates. Third, most Walmart managers were previously Walmart associates and the vast majority do not have any prior training in management. This leads to many Walmart managers either trying to micromanage employees, not behaving professionally, or not knowing how to properly communicate with associates.

pros: None at all, they didn’t think any of this through when they decided to go remote.
cons: TL/TMs are not on the same page, they lie, never respond to you in a timely manner. You’ll be moved around about 3 times before your in a actual queue. They use you to help out other queues then will be last minute and move you somewhere else. No OT unless they so. They have smart mouths, catch attitudes with you when your expressing your concerns. It’s know use going to any of them about anything because they all respond the same way, script reading. These people sit behind their laptops in meetings or calendar events all day. The reliability with max should not exist. Every day through out the shift there are system issues, crashes, slow sites, like you get through a whole shift without having any issues.

pros: If you actually look into the benefits and make use of them they have good ones. The dollar a day college program is what drew me and kept me the last couple of years. I have medical, dental, and vision insurance as well as a 401K. There is an associate stock buying program and they negotiate discounts on cell phone plans, travel, and other stuff if you are into it. If you have the right boss the job is easy enough.
cons: The company is not keeping up with online competitors and is making hours cuts at the store level to compensate. This just leads to more customer frustration which means they are losing in person customers as well. I think they might be going the way of Sears and the other unwieldy giants. My store manager sucks and it shows in the state of the store. Some stores are better than others.

review: Not worth the stress and impact on your mental health
pros: The pay was okay but the town(bentonville) and some of the people were just a bunch of cutt throats from south asia.
cons:
H1B visa mill for low skilled workers.

Company treats foreign workers better than citizens. You will be placed 2 levels below someone that is less competent so theres no reason to stay here and expect to move up the ladder like them.

Company will force you to train offshore resources that make your life a living hell. They get treated better too because of their low cost, while you get treated bad because the offshore resources arent delivering on time and with quality.

There are too many complacent managers/ directors/ vps that are disconnected from the workforce and they will make the worse decisions youve ever seen. 

Company doesnt care about their employees mental health. They will keep you away from family to live in the middle of nowhere. 

Incompetent people that want you to do their work even though they have a higher job title than you.

A ton of project managers/ program managers (ive had 4 of them on one project and they are always asking noob questions and taking up valuable time) that arent adding any value. Their only purpose is to communicate to upper management about your work and your progress. 

If you are an American then be prepared to get treated unfairly. If you are an underrepresented minority then be prepared to experience systemic racism through people that strongly believe in a caste system.

review: Many Pros and Cons when you work at Walmart
pros:
Comradery, friendship with other Associates.
Great experience if you truly like working with people.
401k is excellent
Paid Time Off is generous after a few years
Associate Discounts
cons:
Lots of training, but it's not EFFECTIVE training. Too much online, not enough role playing real day-to-day activities.
Stores are so short-handed that Associates feel every customer is an interruption instead of an opportunity.

pros: If you need money with no experience, then it will pay the bills somewhat. They are lenient about time off and fair about giving you breaks.
cons:
Management constantly has unrealistic demands and will give you conflicting tasks in multiple areas of the store that are far away from each other and then expect you to also jump on the register at any given time and still meet deadlines. 

There is no support or understanding if you don't meet quota due to these restrictions put onto you that are mainly due to poor staffing and management styles.

The constant pressure on your back to perform at a high level with little compensation and little ability to move up will make this job a nightmare fast.

review: Its a decent job. Great for high school or full time college students
pros: Co-wokers were great. Extremely helpful. Hours were pretty good. Especially during the holidays. If I wanted more hours I can easily get them as long as I was willing to be flexible with my position.
cons: Management was beyond terrible. Not all were bad but a scary majority of them were. I recall having arguments with management almost everyday I came in because I refuse to be spoken to like untrained delinquent dog or have people low key threaten me at work, especially at walmart because its never worth it. If I wasn't leaving the store with my hands numb and bleeding (with gloves on) from working in dairy or the freezer, I was told that I wasn't doing a good enough job. The treatment and misuse of workers was just down right rude and intolerable. It may have just been the one I was at but I know plenty of other people who've worked at walmart and said the same about management and treatment of associates. Also the discount doesn't do much in my opinion. I don't see it's purpose

I dread every day of returning to work because the environment is so overwhelmed with freight you cannot perform certain tasks due to the hinderance. pros: great I enjoyed working with Angel. She was an awesome representation of manpower and I can see myself working with Manpower again based on my experience with Angel.
cons: no Every time I needed to deal with my direct employer (ManPower), it was an absolute nightmare. I spent over 16 hours on hold during my first week of employment due to faulty login information and access problems. To this day, even though I am no longer employed through Manpower, they have made an error with my 401K funds and I am unable to access it and unable to get ahold of anyone within Manpower to assist. Their technology, onboarding, and treatment of employees is truly horrendous. I also didn't even know I had a ManPower "boss" outside of my client "boss". The whole experience felt very thrown together, unorganized, and worthless.

pros: If you like discounts on cheap grocery, and a lack of supervision means you can be on your phone a lot with no one caring. Most of the employees are nice, fun to socialize with because they have to deal with the same stressful job and crappy benefits you do.
cons: Pay isn't worth it, benefits are basic. Dealing with crotchety old-timers and ghetto junkies a lot more than you'd like. Standing for long periods of time even on anti-fatigue mats really makes your feet and back ache. The constant "how are you?" To which you will answer 'good' automatically because you hear it way too often to care. The poor quality of things that need to be fixed or replaced, every one complains about the scooters dying in the middle of the store but they can't replace the battery and the problem is they keep them charging 24/7 so the charge is too weak once it's disconnected. Small things like this really add up here, it's just a case of annoyances and how much you can tolerate for the part-time and minimum wage. review: Despite what they say and show the public, Walmart ins't interested in your development.
pros: There are a wide range of jobs and many locations. In some jobs you can find gratifying work.
cons: The culture in some stores and divisions can be toxic, and it's a dice roll on which you're going to get. This can also change when store managers change, and it's effectively ignored by the home office. In fact, even divisions in the Home Office have some pretty brazen behaviors. There is little to no real focus on developing associates professionally in any way except to help Walmart, and even that is fleeting, despite the ads otherwise (like the $1 college tuition, which is to a non-accredited school and only for courses related to your job role). As you move up in the ranks, there are several levels of borderline abusive job roles, where you can expect nearly zero work-life balance. This seems to be true in all divisions.

First Walmart store was extremely good but recent one I transferred did have a bit better pay but the leadership was poor.

pros: You get bonuses once every year i think for having very little or no points (points are what you get if youre late or call in). We have this thing called ppto (protected paid time off) which are minutes/hours of work time that accumulates as you work. It basically lets you get paid to not work. For example, if you have 1 hour of ppto, you can spend it and leave work an hour early or come in an hour late and get paid for that hour and not be given a point. If you have 8 hours of ppto, you can spend all 8 hours and not come in at all for your shift and be paid for the entire day.
cons: Just like at any place, you might get a manager or coworker who is always mean. My store only has 1 which is good

pros: This department is good starting pay wise but that’s about it. If you are in no way part of a marginalized group you will most likely not have an issue, otherwise I warn you tread lightly.
cons: Management is two faced and is too worried about covering their own tails to deal with issues regarding harassment to the point where hardworking people quit their well paying jobs. I am a closeted member of the LGBT community, when it comes to my job I prefer not to share that detail of my life with my coworkers because of past issues I’ve had in prior work environments. I went out on medical leave due to a chronic condition and came back to my entire department debating over my gender identity/sexual orientation. When the harassment of myself as well as multiple other people in our department/store as a whole was reported to upper management, we were told there wasn’t enough “proof” of what had been said to all of us DIRECTLY, to follow through with serious disciplinary action, therefore we were ignored and every day I get to attend work right next to my main harasser who is fully aware of who reported him now. Not to mention if you are physically fit and have a good work ethic you will be used and abused and dismissed the moment you have an issue with how you’re being treated. Employees having worked in said department for over 9 years haven’t been trained on things I was taught to do within my first week of training, or they straight up refuse to take on the tasks that are clearly part of our job description, and guess what, management happily turns a blind eye to this fact so long as the work is getting done by the two people who will actually do it.

pros:
- You get pretty decent benefits
- You have a laid out schedule; telling you when you clock in, take breaks, take lunch, and clock out
cons:
- Distribution of work is wack; people who have seniority in this position don't do very much work and leave it all on people "underneath" them
- Depending on the location, the hours can be flexible or very strict
- At the Walmart I worked at, in order to get a sick day, you had to come in and get your temperature checked and clear it with a manager. Keep in mind this was during the stress of COVID. To add on to their lack of care for workers, absolutely NOTHING in the back was disinfected. Sick workers used computers without wiping off keyboards and mouses, food and trash was left on tables in the lunch room, and absolutely nothing was sanitized. No wonder so many people were calling off sick, and it's a miracle that I made out without getting sick.

pros: None. Unless you're a sadistic manager.
cons: Stores/supervisors have no concept of welfare or regards for employees. Employees are treated like droids, shift supervisors are droids themselves. Any conversation with supervision is a dead end street. Evening Stockers are consistently harassed by shift supervisors on the speed of performance. Shift supervisors are under a pressure cooker from store management to unload as many pallets as possible. A individual employee can complete a impossible number of 20 pallets an hour and still get belated from shift supervisors. The work environment is very hostile and unprofessional. Employees have poor hygiene which affects how Walmart presents itself. It's not uncommon to have seen employees wear tank tops with ripped shirts and pants.

pros: The company will hire just about anyone. It has competitive wages. There is plenty of overtime and the job is considered essential. Many of the coworkers are hard working individuals who have good work ethic. The company offers PTO, incentives, and bonuses.
cons: Management treats employees like a number -easily replaceable- working them like horses until they quit. They don't care if you get hurt in the process as long as you are making them money. They have unreasonable expectations for job performance and micromanage everything. There are no checks and balances to assure employee protection because all of the management collaborates to protect their pockets in so far as to keep bad employees who toxify the work environment by breaking the laws while pushing good hard working employees out the door. Very high turn over rate under the guise of covid problems, and or lazy employees who take leave of work for selfish reasons.

Managers never cared about us and spent time in other parts of store.

review: All I could think about while working was when I could leave the company
pros: The best part of Walmart had to be the streamlined systems surrounding business organization and hiring. Coming into the position, I was able to understand what expectations were for the position and have clear paths toward job growth. The store at which I worked was efficiently laid out and made freight and stocking relatively easy. The co-workers I had in the stock room were also highly friendly and easy to collaborate with.
cons: Management had to be the worst part of working at Walmart. As a student working at one of their "Academy" stores, they were extremely inflexible in terms of my hours. I had to be there at 2 pm every day, even when my classes got out at 1:30 pm. One of my supervisors was also borderline toxic and seemed to be on a sort of power trip. He spoke to and directed a differentially abled worker on my team far too harshly and insensitively, to the point of making me incredibly uncomfortable. My immediate manager also seemed to be a "climber" and didn't seem to care much about his subordinates as much as he cared about his own success.

Again, I do not think i was done any way on purpose nor do I think it happens much at all. This was just my experience. 5 points means you are fired and there's nothing anyone can do to change it...By the time I got to see my points I had 6 so that was a wrap. Hope to get another try at it down the road.

review: Lack of care for disabled and wellbeing of employees
pros: The pay for deli was 15$ hr, you get a walmart discount card after 90 days (3 mo) of working there
cons:
Lack of good management.
Lack of compassionate managers.
Managers do not care about your disabilities or health issues and will write you up for having to use the bathroom when you have IBD or IBS because at times you may be in the bathroom for 15 or so minutes, they believe you just want to play on your phone. (personal experience) 
Management does not care about employees bullying or harassing each other unless it becomes severe sexual harassment.
While they cannot force you to stay on the clock when you are sick- they will still have a point against you even if you work in a food service environment (ACCORDING TO THE CDC YOU ARE NOT SUPPOSED TO WORK IN A FOOD ENVIRONMENT IF YOU ARE VOMITING) They do not care, they want you to work anyway no matter how sick you are unless it is covid- then you must stay out.

pros:
-Not stressful on overnights, enjoy working alone 
-Plenty of opportunities to change positions or go to a different shift. 
-Ability to transfer to other stores. If you decide to move you can always have a job lined up since Walmart is everywhere. 
-Discount card perk is nice but it's excluded on some food and that's a con. Discount should apply on everything across the board. 
-Decent pay for my area WITH my shift differential, not anything to brag about! Overnights gets a 1.50 shift differential, I would not consider it decent pay if I was making only base pay of 13
-Plenty of opportunity to advance and receive promotions. Any of the management positions seem to pay really well. An assistant manager or a "team lead" as they call it apparently makes 65k a year.
-Hour lunches are pretty cool, I like that.
cons:
-Everyone should be paid more and offered better benefits, 13/hr base pay is still really low and I don't understand how anyone could live on that. 
-Health insurance plans aren't good. The deductibles on them are ridiculously high. I expect one of the richest companies to offer 100% employer paid health insurance for their employees. 
-No shift flexibility. Should offer employees choice to work 8s, 10s, or 12s. I'd prefer to work 4 10 hour shifts, always dread going in that 5th day.

review: Fun for a few months, then terrible
pros: Make lots of friends. Easy job. Easy to get employed.
cons:
Management is terrible and rude; they will not give you breaks and make you miss your lunch. They made us backlog our lunches by an hour to make it appear as if we received it on time. We would work 8 hour shifts with only a lunch break and be refused either of our normal 15-minute breaks. The pay isn't worth being treated like that. Other departments in the store had much better management.

HR will refuse to work with your schedule and try to intimidate you into quitting. I was working 55+ hours a week as a cashier, but my application and availability was limited to 25 hours a week. HR did not care and would even increase your hours after complaints.

pros: -Pay was decent, I guess?
cons:
-Terrible work culture. As a new employee, fellow employees will ignore you or are flat-out rude to you if you try and ask any questions.
-Terrible store communication and organization. Having customers constantly get angry with YOU because they need something that is locked up, and then having to spend 10 minutes paging/trying to find the employee with the correct keys, further agitating said customer. Further more, that employee is then irritated with you for spending the time to hunt them down so they can do their job.
-No direction or proper training. I was basically hired, and thrown onto the floor and left to figure out my role on my own, which is difficult when the other employees in the store are all miserable and antisocial, and/or don't speak English.
-This is truly a hard-working/no-reward job. You are simply a number, and nothing more, and you will constantly be treated as such. For your own sanity, I would avoid this place altogether.

review: Good company but could be better. "Sams way" better.
pros:
All the support and fundamentals are there. 
Plenty of opportunities, growth, and benefits.
cons:
To many meetings! They say it's not micro managing but its micro managing.
Also, difficult for a creative person to get projects completed when they always have mandatory meetings that could have been summed up in emails. 

To many opinions on simple projects, that tend to create delays on deadlines.

To many re structures! If you don't have the best productivity for a quarter or two, kiss your job goodbye. So much for associate value.

They also preach about mental health and work life balance but don't really practice it very well. Again, everyones constantly worried about their productivity.

pros: The pay and benefits are good for retail work.
cons:
Management is often rude and hostile, and there's been multiple times where I have been asked/pressured/demanded to stay late, and since I get out at 10 at night, staying late means coming home around midnight. Favoritism in completely rampant in my store. Some of my coworkers blatantly take extra breaks and go to lunch together so their area is without coverage, and management turns a blind eye. If you are not one of the favorite employees, you will be talked down to, yelled at, and likely threatened with your job regularly. 
Keeping the store clean and keeping our meat and produce backroom organized is not a priority at all for management, until it becomes bad enough that we have to dedicate an entire day to fixing these issues instead of stocking and assisting customers. 
Having the equipment you need to do your job is a nonexistent concept at my store, and managers usually get annoyed if you bring that up to them. In general, it is difficult to approach management with any sort of issues, as even if they are around, they may brush you off, ignore you, or scream at you.

review: 80% of workload with 10% or less staffing
pros: You get to run your business without other management being involved.
cons:
You are expected to do majority of the work for the building with less then 10% of the total store staff. A lot of responsibilities. Responsible for total store operations without total store operations pay. You will be working all night if you want to succeed. You will out work every other member of management in your building and get paid the same of less.
You can work 4 days on and 3 days off. It does not seem like you really get the days off of work though.
Consistent calls when you are off and no time to recover.
Easily walk 10-20 miles nightly.
