pros: Working at Walmart keep you busy. Time goes by really fast.
cons:
Training is not existent. If you need help because you don’t know how to do something ( because they don’t train you) you have to find someone to help you. 
They take forever to put your schedule up at least from being a new hire. Asked them daily and all they say is that they put it before they leave. And guess what, no and the end of the day. People with kids or that need rides like me is a problem having a schedule day by day. They tell you all kind of rules and policy on your first day and then even managers ignore when a cashier so busy chitchatting while customers are waiting to be ringed up. None is there to take over your shift when you are done. But you cannot leave without telling one of your leader that is impossible to find. They make you install this app to contact your coworkers or managers/ coach , team leaders but none is actually active on it. No discrimination is not allowed but is not true. As a person with Social anxiety and depression on my first day I was made fun of on the spot including my leaders. List can go on and on.

review: Job with good benefits but poor hours
pros:
-Walmart has a great Leave of Absence (LOA) policy and system which allows you to go away intermittently or for extended period of time and it only takes a few minutes to file a claim.
- Walmart has an associate discount card that gives all employees a 10% off card that works on all Division 1 store items (basically, any item that isn’t food or “Walmart” brand).
-It’s super easy to move around the store as they always need extra workers in different departments
cons:
-terrible work shifts, you must work 1 of 3 shifts at my location, which are: 4am-1pm, 1pm-10pm and 10pm to 7am. My old location would allow you to work hours that fall in to your availability hours. So, this seems to be different at every store
-Difficult to move up at Walmart, I’ve been with Walmart for 4 years and have always had above satisfactory on my employee rating, and have never had the opportunity to move up in the store( now, I am a full-time student and a current military employee so this could have a big affect on that)

cons: Honestly, the biggest issue for me was the customers that walked into my Walmart. I had worked in fast food and retail for years but working for Walmart the customers here are so different. The types of customers that rolled into the Walmart I worked at were terribly mean. I've heard them scream over basically nothing, I've seen them throw things I've been called every name in the book even while trying to stay nice and keep my cool but their tough to handle especially if you work night shift. As well as the lack of communication from management and the never ending call offs from your co workers you will always go home stressed and crying feeling over worked and partially dead.

pros:
1. Reasonable wages - about $12.30/hr to start in Albuquerque, NM.
2. It's a job.
cons:
1. We either didn't have the tools to do the jobs they asked me to or the tools were broken, yet the manager still yelled at us if something didn't get done (she knew the tools weren't there or were broken).
2. Minimal training = angry customers. You really do have to learn on the job because they don't train you much. You just have to figure things out as you go and when you're new that means customers get angry when you don't know certain things.
3. There are so many customers to help constantly and so many tasks that must get done. It was very very busy, at least when I worked there.

pros: Meeting many people and chatting with them makes the day go by fast along with the fact that the store is basically Always a very busy place.
cons: Nonsense among co-workers and they could pay people more an hour.

review: Looking to relocate to Charlotte, NC

pros:
• Great Pay. Stocking teams make $17+ an hour.
• Teamwork focused job
• Good Hours. Almost guaranteed 40 hours every week. 
• VERY ACTIVE. If you’re not used to it, it will be hard but I personally enjoy it.
cons:
• The customers are a nightmare to work with sometimes. Especially if you work the front end of the store (but luckily that’s not stocking teams).
• If you have a complaint, management will take days or even weeks to change it or they don’t even bother. 
• DIRTY. You will be smelling smells you’ve never smelled before and ones you’ll never want to smell again. My jeans always leave the store covered in gray dust and dirt from the floors.
• Walmart hires EVERYONE and I mean literally everyone. I have personally dealt with some of the creepiest, scariest, and more hate filled people. Some still work there no matter how many complaints from workers there are. Management will only move them to a different part of the store instead of firing.

Zero competency, and fire people left and right, no matter how hard you work or how good you are at your job. If you don't bend to their every whim, straight to the curb

review: Below Average. Pay here is good, compared to other places around me (California). Work place culture though is toxic.
pros:
-Pay here is higher than other places. ($17.30 for Digital Shoppers in California)
-If you're full time you get decent benefits
-If you stay here long enough you can use this place as a stepping stone. They offer their Guild Education program where you can go to online college and the employer pays for it.
cons:
-Toxic work culture.
-They will focus on numbers, and regardless of whether or not you have an input or an idea that will help them achieve there goal, your voice doesn't matter here.
-Hard to move up unless you have connections.

pros: Very professional and always kind. They also take any problems you may have and instantly remove it. If you have any trouble with something they are there to always help and make you feel like you can go to them anytime. I like how when you get pulled in the office. You’re not scared to get in trouble, instead you’re calm and relaxed they don’t make you scared.they are always flexible if you have plans to go somewhere and need time off, or anything that requires PTO or call outs and you don’t want to be dinged for it.
cons: Unable to receive overtime here and there. And if you gain just a few minutes they will cut a few hours off your schedule to combat the overtime. In a way it makes sense but not if some have only a few minutes rather than hours. The working all weekends and holidays it’s rough as well, you tend to miss out on a lot of family events or opportunities to go out and do something’s on weekends.

pros: It was easy to get hired.
cons: "Full Time" can be as little as 8 hours per week. If you miss a day for a legitimate medical emergency, even with documentation from the ER, management will still harass you and threaten to fire you. Training was insufficient and abusive. I was SCREAMED at by a supervisor for "wasting time" rotating inventory, and told to just "shove the (expletive) wherever it fits, don't worry about expiration dates". There were too few handheld scanners for all employees to actually get one. Also, this location has a habit of hiring too many new applicants, essentially creating a hostile work environment, where employees are in constant competition with their coworkers in hopes of keeping their job.

review: It is decent for a first time job
pros: The only pros that really come with it is if there are people there you can communicate with and have positive attitudes. Otherwise it is a really boring, lengthy and hard labor job. But sometimes you meet customers from all around the world and some really enjoy conversing.
cons: This job can be back breaking and sometimes a real pain. I don't always get equipment I need and I cannot successfully aid any customers when they ask for help. I have worked their long enough that they want me to work full time. However does not give me the desired flexibility to have my Friday and Saturday off to spend with family. It may say it is a family company but really they will work you really hard and sometimes in environments that make you sick and some days I have to struggled to get to such a far away location. The company also did not approve of my transfer request and corporates did little to help and just shut my case down immediately. All in all. Depending on the location it is a decent workspace. Otherwise be prepared for a shocking environment to work in. I have so many reasons as to why I want to leave the company.

pros: Ha! What a joke... None.
cons:
You do so much for little money. Meanwhile, others barely work aka the brown noses (low ranking workers who kiss top ones behind and more chat than work). The top ones (leads, managers, etc) don't work. Actually, correction: they work when someone with a higher position is around. Otherwise, they stroll around the store (hey! It's not a park btw) chatting with other lazy/entitled coworkers. The top ones will yell at you, snap at you, demand that you do everything super fast, but in front of customers they're nice and sweet. What a bunch of fake people!! Oh, and there are a lot of gossip, intrigues, back stabbing, name calling and loads, loads, LOADS of control. Btw, the top ones instead of working can also be watching you through the dozens of cameras instead of actually working.
Oh, and there's this little room where the top ones want to talk (snap at you) when they're not satisfied with you. Since they love intimidation and control, they don't do that in front of others. They take you to this room with no cameras btw. So they can abuse you as much as they can with lots of gaslighting, lies, more yelling, aggressive body language, etc. That place is disgusting!!!!!

review: Direction Forced By Politics Rather Than The Right Thing To Do
pros:
Good Bonus (if achieved)
Restricted Stock Options
You'll gain a good understanding of retail
Opportunities are there if you fit the profile
cons:
Leadership don't have direction, and you could find yourself with nothing to do for the first 6 months of the year while they are still confirming budgets.
Don't expect praise for good work but expect to be hauled up for the slightest problem
People in technology are looked down on from people in business, and can sometimes put a team together just to take credit for your work and interfere
Evals are pointless as your grade is based on a political discussion, not what you actually achieve
Too focused on qualifications rather than the actual ability to do the job

-I grew as a person and as a leader while being here, and enjoyed developing associates.
-Good pay and benefits in management positions, especially considering I never actually completed college.
-Working in a store gives those of us who are there a tactical advantage during times like Covid, and the ice storm in TX, allowing us to provide ourselves and our families with the things we need.
cons:
-Leadership higher than store management tends to be bureaucratic, out of touch, and not all on the same page.
-No work/life balance for management. I voluntarily left after 15 years due to mental health. (WM is not all to blame, I had/have other things going on concurrently in my personal life that never got resolved because I had to only work.)
-No reward or validation for going above and beyond. This depends on the store manager, though. I have had good ones that did recognize, but the past couple years, at best, all we got was thank you, exactly once a year at evaluation time. And everybody got it, even the sucky managers with ugly departments and unhappy associates.
-While there are plenty of customers who are just normal people like you and me, a lot of them are absolute abominations to society.

pros: You will get alot of experience working for the Fortune 1. You get a 10% discount off certain items at the store. They created Live Better University where associates can go to college for free. (they are expanding to have more degrees and majors ) Salaried members of management receive up to a 25% bonus every year. The 401k match is 6%. You receive stock options. Associates are nice and willing to help you learn along the way. The culture is strong and associates live by the Walmart way.
cons: Working at Walmart is baptism by fire, you are constantly drinking out of a firehose. There is no real training program. There is no work life balance. The culture is always on most associates always have their work phone on; early mornings, late nights, weekends and even on vacation. There is a ton of leadership turnover.

(they are expanding to have more degrees and majors ) Salaried members of management receive up to a 25% bonus every year. The 401k match is 6%. You receive stock options. Associates are nice and willing to help you learn along the way. The culture is strong and associates live by the Walmart way.
cons: Working at Walmart is baptism by fire, you are constantly drinking out of a firehose. There is no real training program. There is no work life balance. The culture is always on most associates always have their work phone on; early mornings, late nights, weekends and even on vacation. There is a ton of leadership turnover.

review: it's a job. they protect pedos, though.
pros: good pay. hour-long lunch breaks.
cons:
let a predator who followed my child coworkers home and wouldn't stop trying to hang out with them + make sexual advances off the hook because he said he was "being targetted." nearly every girl in the department went to management and told them about their terrible experiences with him and they did not care. also offer no support for people in abusive households, they seemed to not even understand the concept. either that or they purposely brushed it off as nothing.

also, they made us use broken equipment to the point everyone has to stand around until they're able to piggyback off someone else.

pros: 1 hour lunch, unpaid, 10% discount only on select items by walmart.
cons: Incompetent managers, they squeeze every ounce of work out of the minimum wage they pay. They didn't have enough carts for the amount of customers they had. The cart machine was broken. Empty promises made by management that they're ordering new ones but they don't arrive. They only had about 150 carts for a very busy location near a beach in a big city on black Friday while it was pouring rain and they still want us to go out and collect carts that aren't even there. Don't waste your time work for target or something.

review: Will work you to death. Unsafe work environment.
pros:
The pay is good because they wouldn’t be able to get anyone to do what they’re asking otherwise.
The benefits are good
cons:
They will work you like a machine. Till your body literally starts to break down, then they will fire you if you don’t hit your numbers they set for you. Which are very hard to maintain.

The environment is unsafe. I personally saw several people get hurt, and then I myself got hurt. Which they blamed on me, and punished me for by writing me up. I sprained my ankle because their was a drain open inside my pulling isle on the ground and I stepped in it. It wasn’t supposed to be open but they said I wasn’t looking where I was going. I was just trying to pull as fast as possible so I didn’t get fired. They then gave me 4 days to recover and then raised back my numbers I had to hit back to pre injury which I was no longer able to physically obtain. I ended up leaving.

Dealing with unruly customers can be difficult if you do not know how to manage stress well

I had 2 of my other managers go on medical leave and when I picked up all of their responsibilities there was no compensation. As a manager the Job can come with tons of stress. I am 25 and on 3 blood pressure pills and an anxiety pill. That is why I am now seeking new employment

pros: 40+ every week. No punishment for overtime, unless you milked it. Fair pay for the customer service industry. I've been in customer service for over a decade and Walmart: 1. Genuinely cares about us employees. 2. Training is GREAT. You dont go out on your own until you're ready and confident in your ability. And if you want to learn a different role they'll make time for you to train there too, no questions asked. 3. Culture. Walmart culture centers on love. Kindness. Just be a good human, they'll support you. 4. Humanity over profit. SUPER RARE IN ANY INDUSTRY. They put PEOPLE OVER PROFIT. EVERYTIME. I love my job. I've for sure worked waaayyyyyyy worse.
cons: Do not be late. No call outs. You're devoting yourself to building the Walmart brand and culture. It's not really a con. You're working to build up Walmart, that's why they hired you. So they expect you to deliver on your end of the deal. Like I said.... basic humanity.

The need to save money will often come at the cost of team's mental health and against the advice of expertise. Not a lot of fast technical growth, so if you want to work on building new systems, this is not the place for you.

It's not the most difficult work in the world

In addition, yearly reviews are not in-depth (thus, depriving you of real improvement), while the yearly raises are either on par with, or less than inflation

review: Experience may vary from Store to Store
pros:
* Accessible. Will usually accept most types of people for as long as they meet the standard requirements for employment.
* Wage Growth. This may vary from store to store, region by region, but in just the past 5 years wages have grown from federal minimum to almost $15/hr in some regions.
* Diverse Team. This varies from store to store, but often times you will find yourself among wholesome and diverse coworkers who may not care much about the company, but will care a lot about you (management is hit or miss here).
* Benefits. If you're full-time, expect benefits after your probationary period (between 30 and 90 days). If you're part-time, you might as well go for open enrollment because it takes 12 months to get benefits.
* Transferrable. After 90 days, you may choose to change departments, store locations, or even shift into an entire different division (store, club, distribution, home office, etc).
cons:
* Policy over People. It will always hang over the heads of hourly associates. Some exceptions can be made, but if you're late too often it's an automatic termination even if management doesn't want to actually terminate the associate.
* Demanding Job "Positions". Crosstraining and flexible skillsets are common and associates will find themselves working jobs they're not hired to do.
* Abusive Customers. Most people view Walmart very poorly and will extend that perception onto associates in a manner where it's outright abuse. Once an associate takes off their vest and leaves the store the same customers can be delightful and kind.
* Flies. Yes, literal flies. This one may sound like a joke, but it's a truth that might not be exclusive to Walmart. I have personally worked in two different stores and flies in the break room is almost always excessive and out of control. The primary issue? Open top trash cans. It's been almost 10 years and it's still seems to be standard to just keep open top trash cans. The countermeasure is usually store-use fly paper off the shelf and one of those blue light ECOLABs (which honestly never seems to do that good of a job).

review: Not a bad place to work
pros:
I worked a little over a year at a Walmart Super center as a Cap 2 and I have a very positive opinion of my time there. This was my first job as a 16 year old and they were one of the only places that would hire me. Right off the bat they offered me $14/hr ($1 above minimum at the time) and once minimum was raised to $14, they quickly gave everyone in my position a raise to $17.
The workers were really cool and fun to be around and I made many good friends. Management was extremely chill.
cons:
I did not enjoy the customers.
The ASM in charge of scheduling would sometimes not schedule associated for two weeks straight (including full-time associates.)
The 10% card doesn’t work for everything in the store.

Company keeps eliminating positions, wants computers to run the store. Everyone is out to get everyone else, there’s no loyalty to employees. Most store managers are there through the buddy system and you’ll be doing their job for them while they work a couple hours a day at most and hide in their office. You’ll also be cussed out by at least 3 customers per day for just doing your job. Most ASMs leave within a year or have a nervous breakdown.

review: If you have already learned how to work for a corporation......you'll do well here
pros:
If you are consistently on time and always there for every scheduled shift; If you ask your co-workers when you need information; if you are flexible (within reason) about hours and scheduled days; if you scrupulously avoid clicks and gossip; The mgm't will LOVE you.

Quarterly profit sharing is based on how well your facility does. The location I was at regularly got really nice bonuses, sometimes in the hundreds of dollars.
cons: attendance is rigidly enforced -- unless you know in advance and talk with your supervisor about it or you can do a shift change with someone else on your team. Poor attendance impacts reviews, quarterly profit sharing, ability to move to other departments, and so on.

pros:
Good location I work in.
Customers are good some aren’t the best.

I have my good days occasionally.

review: Too much to do, and not enough time to do it.
pros: You can listen to music/podcasts/audiobook/youtube videos while you work. If they give you a solo assignment for the night, you can break whenever you want as long as you finish.
cons: Right from the beginning, I realized I was in for it because they hired me no question, no interview, nothing. The upper management never got to know me and they still don't know who I am after 6 months. They are more than aware that morale is low, because they go around almost nightly repeating "we appreciate you" to me and the team. At the same time, they tell you constantly how replaceable you are. THEY DO NOT TRAIN. It took me 3-4 months to be able to go in and say to myself "I got this." Every night, I was thrown in with the sharks. They use online programs called ULearns to prime you for the job. They're terrible. Youre most likely to get some ex-military hard-ass "coach" manager who still thinks they're in Vietnam. I respect the military, but its no excuse to be a......whatever. They stress that you concern yourself with things that have nothing to do with you, like what time they left the shift previous and what high position manager plans to walk through the store. I go in ON TIME, they tell me what they need from me, I do it, I go home. That's it. THAT is my concern. They CONSTANTLY spit jargon they expect new people to already know (zoning, topstock, vizpicking, QPC, plugging, TC, on-hand, baling) and share news with the expectation that everyone is on the same page already. You could spend 4 nights in a row consistently in a section you know well and are still learning, and then on night 5 youre thrust into a brand new section with zero prior knowledge.

review: On the job training with room for growth

cons: - Difficult communication with upper management within main store - Difficult implementation with devices/ programs used for inventory purposes - Communication is difficult with the program used to request L.O.A/F.M.L - Little forgiveness in regard to the unpredictability of chronic illnesses

pros: Getting to met lots of customers and having lots of conversations with them it helps with communication skills
cons: Managers don’t follow the rules they send you to lunch too early or too late rarely do they send you on time and since they send you at the wrong times they’ll tell you to clock out for the day when you go to lunch instead of clocking out for a meal so that it doesn’t show up as the workers being on lunch at the wrong time so they won’t get in trouble and the store won’t get fined and sometimes they would never send me on not one break my whole shift. Also my set schedule would always get changed without the managers telling me or asking me if it was ok which is against the law and when they would add a day to my schedule and I wouldn’t come in because i didn’t know because nobody would let me know that my schedule was changed and I’d get in trouble and get written up. Over all they have really sucky managers which makes working at Walmart a living nightmare. I would never recommending working at Walmart to anyone.

Then Walmart will lie and try everything to come up with excuses for why you were fired which doesn't even follow the procedures called out in their employe handbook.

review: Don't work here if proper professional communication is important to you.
pros:
-somewhat decent pay but not a livable wage
-miniscule associate discount (10%)
-fairly flexible hours
cons:
-Sexually harassed and verbally abused by customers regularly with no help from management
-very little lenience on attendance despite not letting you come in if you've had even the slightest symptoms of COVID in the past ten days
-IMPOSSIBLE to get a phone call through to the store management. Apparently they now put the phones in the empty dressing rooms so no one has to answer them because no one feels like being even remotely helpful. Very professional!
-As a transgender employee I'm constantly deadnamed by my coworkers despite having my preferred name on my name tag from day one. Some of my coworkers have watched me clock in just so they could see my birth name and intentionally use it instead of my preferred name.
-often will not have the proper tools needed to work, and will be expected to "make do" anyways, even if the missing equipment makes the task next to impossible
-despite being in a mask mandated state, we aren't allowed to tell customers or coworkers to put a mask on because we may "lose business"
-the higher ups don't even seem to understand how the grocery pick up department operates and it's literally sad how out of touch with the associates they are

review: Advancement opportunities and family-like atmosphere are big pluses.
pros: Good opportunities to advance and get promotions. Family-like atmosphere with most of your co-workers and supervisors. Breaks are adhered. PTO. Good benefits.
cons: VERY stressful public environment. Customers can be VERY demanding, rude and impatient. Management will often do nothing if there is an irate customer and you are the target of their wrath. Scheduling and hours you work is/are erratic and inconsistent...no stability with your hours at all. Store managers will pull you from your job to put you up front (cashier) instead of hiring more help up front. This leads to your own "area" being behind schedule/under performing and you often have to scramble to get your own work done and then this becomes an issue and then: STRESS. Some coworkers are malicious (not toward customers but toward other employees) due to jealousy, immaturity and their own insecurities. There is often backstabbing, gossip, pettiness, etc. within employee relationships and management does not care.

pros: The community is amazing. My fellow associates are amazing people and I've forged some amazing friendships. They make the job somewhat pleasant. Another positive is that the work itself isn't too bad! It can be pretty physical and sometimes menial, but fine! I love my (initial) department and my team.
cons: The biggest factor is how understaffed we are and how much the management of my store just ... don't care. In my own team, we have 3 associates when we're supposed to have 12. It makes for a very, very stressful environment when I cannot get enough of my work done. The management just don't schedule people that they do have, so other departments always need help with customer service, so they grab associates from other places no matter how busy they are. This has caused just pure exhaustion in me and my associates. I can name so many who are ready to leave at the drop of a hat because it's becoming draining and miserable to go to work. I get paid 11.50 to help do everything in the store, half of which are positions that get paid so much more than I do. Also, with the shifts to teams, I went from working in 1 department to 6, but we never got new associates.

pros: Early shift start times are okay
cons:
Overworked and underpaid. Not a positive culture. If you are not a brown noser or lazy you won’t get promoted. It’s not about what you know it’s who you know. You can a great worker, dependable and well rounded but won’t get any recognition but you can be the laziest worker but if you know the right people that’s all you need. I even had the people lead approach me in hostile manner stating
, “oh is your name …, oh okay because I heard you haven’t been taking lunches, so why is that?”. This is what the company promotes. She also approached another employee to say, “oh I heard you was taking about like what’s up you got a problem or what?”. To my surprise she has gotten another promotion where she will now be making over 70k a year. I have over 10 plus years retail experience, 2 years management experience, 5 plus years call center experience, an associates of science and a Bachelor of Arts but they wouldn’t pay me more than $11.90/hr.

cons: The management does not communicate with one another, they let their favorites get away with murder and push the hard working employees to the break.

review: Some stores are better to work at than others
pros: The pay is on the higher side in my area for entry-level jobs. I did work at another store for a year before transferring to this location, and the management was well put together and respected the associates. Upper management was great at both stores I worked at.
cons:
Lots of physical work. I was constantly having to lift very heavy totes (80+lbs) by myself at strange angles throughout the day. There is always a lack of staffing (and then the associates get blamed for the work not getting done). The number of orders we could receive in a day kept rising, but we were not staffed correctly to be able to keep up. No one is on the same page.

As I stated above, I did transfer from a different store in a mid-sized city to a very small town Walmart. Unfortunately, the lower management is mostly from the area and tends to be extremely biased against outsiders. This made my experience there awful. I was constantly being accused of things I would absolutely never do by my manager. My manager also thinks that COVID-19 is a joke and always took off his mask in front of associates and would not keep his distance. Many of the associates/managers/supervisors refuse to follow The One Best Way (Walmart's universal procedures).

pros:
$1 per day college (select college for certain degrees) books paid for

annual bonus (depending on profits) for salaried roles
cons:
Potential long hours depending on current management and condition of the total store.
Declines in profits or other situations could determine a smaller bonus or none at all after a hard year's work. You don't know what bonus you will get until the end of Walmart's fiscal year.

pros: Most of the management insists on you're taking your breaks according to law. They have been one of the first large corporations in the past to recognize same-sex marriages for benefits, to raise the wage well above minimum for all members.
cons: Although numbers are important to any business, the pressure on the management to meet their numbers goals appears to be so intense that they often act out very rudely to the associates. Also, there are numerous managers at the general store manager level who have no idea how to speak to a fellow human being unless they're a customer, that is, using name calling, shouting, accusations of laziness without investigation. In short unprofessional behavior. Now I hear from colleagues there when I quit that management has been cut in half and basically have to compete for their jobs at all times. Also hierarchy has been removed. So no manager can specialize in their department and get to know it well.

pros: Working at Walmart helped me get through school. They are a great company and I would highly recommend them to anyone wanting to work while getting an education.
cons: So far I do not have any cons. They were always helpful and gave me time off when I needed it and were more than willing to work with my changing schedule for school.

pros: There is some security in working at Walmart, so long as you stay out of trouble, meet or exceed your goals, and show up for work when scheduled (not exceeding your point total in absences). There are always opportunities to change job titles or move up in the company if you wish.
cons: The customer base is not very understanding or knowledgeable about how retail works. There are also many employees at Walmart who have been employed for years without bothering to improve themselves or their own work ethic. Unfortunately since the company seemingly abandoned yearly evaluations (At least, I can't remember the last time I had one), there is no incentive for improvement.

review: I want a refund on my 4 years being there.
pros:
If you're a lazy worker- then you can get away with so many things. I've seen it.
Other than that- nothing.
cons:
Bully bosses, expecting more and more with the GOOD workers. Management is crap. Will even flirt with you, but you can't say anything if you want to keep your job, I'm sure. I got pinned against the wall in the mens bathroom when I tried to clean it. Never really told anyone because I knew no one would care.
We had employees having sex in the bathroom approved by the same guy that touched me in turn for some pills to "give them an hour." 
I lost my hair from the stress (among other people.) 
I constantly heard one of my ex buddies wanting to slice his wrists every night when he had to come in. THAT says something.

It's nothing but a prison.

pros: The pay very well for Store Managers.

review: Realy depends on which store you work at
pros:
Bonuses (full time only)
Multiple breaks
Flexible (part time only)
Good training programs
Help with education
Discount
If you're at a good store, the overall attitude of employees is positive
cons: If you are at a bad store (one where upper management really doesn't care) it can be frustrating trying to be productive and fulfill your duties. This is because the bad attitude from upper management trickles down to the part time employees (who are essential in helping the department managers). At stores like this, most people around you have a bad attitude and don't want to put in effort. Working at walmart can be a good opportunity and work experience. However, it would be smart to research the rankings of the particular stores you are thinking of applying to.

review: Great Team, Not a Fantastic Company
pros: Fantastic team who I enjoy spending the day with and greatly appreciate. A flexible schedule, which works well with college and daycare. The chance to learn about the most commonly prescribed outpatient medications and medical terminology. The pharmacy is a dynamic workplace and is seldom quiet or dull.
cons: We don't generally have enough help and we're all very stressed throughout the day. Like with many places, facing challenges imposed by the pandemic have been difficult. We were barely staffed to handle a day's work beforehand, now we have to somehow keep the place afloat with multiple members in quarantine. Our market manager is also fantastic, but those higher than him, less so. While I was very pleased to gain the opportunity give vaccinations, it is unfortunate that those of us with this additional training and responsibility are not given any addition to our wages as compensation. I have recently found out that people in my position with less experience are being paid a fair bit more than we are at nearby Walmarts, which makes me feel undervalued. If it were not for my fabulous team, I would definitely be out of there. My manager has said the same thing about us, as she'd otherwise prefer a location that is much less stressful with a better commute. I have been searching on Indeed for a few weeks to see what other opportunities are available.

pros: None. I wouldn't recommend working at this company to anyone. The pay and benefits are just OK, but they work you to death so you can't even enjoy the few "incentives" they give. I've heard that other areas of the company are better than the apparel department, so that is hopeful.
cons: Poor leadership, everyone is overworked and the atmosphere is oppressive. They treat their employees terribly and the employees treat the suppliers terribly. It's a vicious cycle. The reason for Walmart's success is because they threaten their suppliers into submitting to them so they can "provide value" to the customer... but it's never been about the customer, it's about filling the upper management's pockets full of money and walking over anyone who gets in their way.

review: Is Working At Walmart Fitting for You ?
pros: The best part about working at Walmart is getting to meet new people each and every day. Another plus is getting to develop and have a great relationship with your co-workers. Walmart may seem like a chaotic place to work, but once you find the right people with whom you get along, it makes the job more worth-wild.
cons: The downside of working at Walmart is getting customer complaints. Sometimes there are certain situations where things are simply out of your control and you have to deal with these problems head-on. One thing to remember is not take things too personally when it comes to criticism either. Your hard-earn efforts will pay off in the long run. You just have to push through it!

pros:
You dont talk to many people
You can listen to music
You get free water bottles
cons:
They over work you for little pay
When you get injured ( like I did ) they make YOU pay for all the medical bills. I had to pay for physical therapy and Painkillers which resulted in $300 which I didn't even make in 2-4 weeks. 
They say they understand schooling. THEY DONT. if your in any sort of schooling no matter how old you are they will REFUSE to give you full time
The employees were Harsh and never wanted to talk to others so your never talking to anyone not even your own coworkers.
The Boss was never there for me to fill out a digital check so I had to get paper checks the whole time working
They never gave me my check for training and the first week of working because they misspelled my name.
They will call you to come to work even if it's not your day to work.

review: Gain a variety of insights on the business
pros:
Big data; Large; Complex; 3rd Party Systems and custom in-house development.

In an IT world, Walmart has it all and at great scale. So if you like variety and complexity, they deliver.
cons:
Leadership is critical to survival and good leadership is very hit and miss, with great leadership rare. There's also no true technology strategy other than fly by the seat of our pants and hope we deliver something! Where stability was never a worry, it seems corporate has lost itself and thus, laid off more people than ever before, causing those left to be very stretch. It's also caused a 'cut-throat' environment as individuals worry about their stability and performance, which created an environment of 'pointing fingers'. 

The total compensation is quite lacking, given the breadth of responsibility and accountability. You can get much more money at half the stress elsewhere.

review: Not a family oriented company anymore
pros: They promote people quickly even if they aren’t qualified to do the job. If you like not having the same days off and rotating three different shifts each week, then this job is for you.
cons: Terrible upper management and no support. They are reducing associates and management overall so there aren’t enough people to complete the work. People are having strokes and heart attacks due to the stress. They promote deceitful and dishonest people. The company overall does not care who you are, so teamwork is NOT a thing because everyone knows you can get away with anything—why work hard if you don’t have to? Also, they make you think the benefits are wonderful. I’ve never had worse! I selected the best option—one doctor visit ended up being $300+.

pros: Workplace culture: "homely" may be an odd term, but it's the best description to explain my relationship with the store I worked in. Micromanagement was minimal and employees were trusted to complete tasks at their own pace.
cons:
Low wages: pay is above minimum wage but still quite low; raises are not guaranteed and have not kept pace with inflation.
Poor corporate support structures: there were always shortages of new employees, equipment, or even repairs regardless of what we ordered from upper management.

* Most employees have to work on weekends and most holidays.

pros: When I first started it was a nice atmosphere. I got to make peoples days by complementing them and just doing little deeds of kindness. I was also able to meet a lot of cool people there!
cons: After two weeks of working there the atmosphere went down very fast. People started saying bad stuff to me about each other. I had managers allow other co-workers to get away with saying "no" when they didn't wanna do it so id end up doing it (just seemed like a lot of favoritism happened there). It was just a bad job in my opinion. I don't plan on recommending anyone to work there or plan on going back.

pros: You get to influence hundreds of people with their future careers with the company. You get experience in both a virtual classroom and in person. Generous time off, good benefits.
cons: Often canceling PTO due to staffing shortages (but this is pretty common now in 2021) This position is only meant to be held for 18-24 months and then you will need to go back into operations within a Walmart store or be willing to move to Bentonville to continue a career in the facilitating world.

pros: Decent benefits, ability to promote, many options and services to choose from to work in

pros: There's a 5 word minimum
cons: After 10 years, its all the same. They don't make informed decisions, meaning they listen to one side and react. They put you in dangerous situations all for profit. They are not diverse. Every restructure I've seen seems to revolve around maintaining the token black person as the token. When you get too many, they have to find a way to get them out. If you ever see 2 salaried black managers.... one word...  restructure. You notice how long it too for walmart to make a statement about race? Its because they don't care. They abuse the labor of salaried employees. They own you. This is not a family friendly company. They make it safe for the shoppers, yes... but for employees, they expect you to sacrifice everything. Just to put more money in people's pockets that you'll never see.

I had to call out sick with the flu one week, I used my points, ect. but it still felt like management retaliated by ignoring any requests I made for help in the weeks following that.

review: Trying to believe in Walmart for awhile, but they've lost touched with their employees.
pros:
My hours (time of day that is)
Understanding and patient customers 
I was grateful to have a job during the Pandemic when so many lost theirs.
cons:
Management (and not to be really negative, but)
 - No training happens in store. We watch a video. And that's the extent of it. 
 - When something is needed, it is always demanded, and in a rush. Then while in the middle of it, many times your yanked to help out in another of store (because of high turn over) , then they're frustrated original job's not done.
 -Double standard (when regional Mgr in store its one way, otherwise it's sometimes cut corners.
 -Total disrespect (certain mgrs talk down to you. Try to make you feel stupid, with the "I am better than you, I don't need to help you, talk to you, you are a subordinate, but I know it all attitude" 
 -Could go on, but everyone hears the news how other places raising wages, incentives, etc.. while Walmart does nothing. I can be a stocker making say $14/hour, then go to a different department and go down to $11 or $12.. forget about my "exciting" 2% raise each year,.. somehow that'll get lost in the.shuffle..

pros: It was an okay experience.

•Favoritism worse than ANY place I’ve ever worked before. If you ain’t liked at walmart I promise 10/10 they’ll make your life harder than it needs to be in more ways than one. 
•Strict rule book/ not so understanding of personal issues that come up 
•Customers are another breed 
•Lots and lots and lots of disrespect from both (generally elder) coworkers and management alike in my experience, at my store. I’d still recommend working at Walmart however, on the off chance that you can find a store with good management, it makes a WORLD of a difference when your managers are respectful and actual leaders. (:

pros: Huge company means opportunity to move around. Pretty stable. Healthy culture depends on strong teams and good leadership. Lifers are few and far between in the Bay Area but it’s legend in Home Office. Not as bad as people think Walmart is, not as great as they think they are. If you find a good management team, hang on for dear life since that will set the tone for everything - work/life balance and team culture, push back and stakeholder management, negotiating for headcount. If you do well (meets or above) annual raise is basically guaranteed and the company is doing strong enough to consistently meet goals for bonus. “Unlimited” PTO for eComm teams.
cons: Prime example of being a cog in the corporate machine. Been at the company over 5 years through multiple reorgs, the most recent one in fall 2020 was the most brutal - levels simply removed so people demoted or promoted seemingly at random, people placed in roles where it’s a poor fit, and recruiting/HR is a mess. Getting jerked around happens enough to you or people you know that eventually you just feel grateful to have a job or fed up enough to leave. Always under resourced so stress can be high. Internal promotions are standard 10% so you better negotiate in high on base salary while you can since RSUs and vacation (even before Unlimited policy) are standard per level too. It just means the longer you stay at the company, the less likely you may be making market rate.

pros: Benefits (Health, Dental, Vision, and Education), Not Micro-Managed, Convenient for you to do your own shopping and for lunch.
cons: Management doesn't follow policy. long term retaliation for contacting the ethics department. The lowest common denominator are promoted. If you are educated or experienced you don't get promoted. Low pay and very little if any raises. Your raises aren't base on performance. No acknowledgement for good work. Some employees were acknowledged by mgt and on social media for their 5 yr anniversary while a few others weren't. You feel invisible. Some people are never interviewed for other positions no matter their qualifications. Management already knows who they want and will tell them to apply then do two other interviews just to appear to be following policy. They don't turn in accident reports because it affects their bonuses and you can't get workers comp if needed.

review: Not sure if it’s worth it
pros:
Decent Pay “if” you work your scheduled hours only.
Matching 401K after a year 
Inexpensive Health & Dental Insurance
Certain levels of management can bonus anywhere from 3%-50% of their salary at the end of the year.
My level of management bonus starts at 15% and ends at up to 30% of my salary per year.
cons:
Salary vs Hourly expectations differ greatly. I do not recommend anyone to become a salary manager. You will end up making less money per hour based on the number of hours you have to work in order to get everything that’s required done. 
Low wages for Most frontline hourly associates.
Stressful position

pros: Walmart lures you in with decent starting salary and the\ promise of career opportunities
cons: After restructure career opportunities are much harder as the hierarchy has thinned dramatically. They say you work a 50 hour work week, I have never seen that except on paper. They underpay their cashiers, their cart pushers, they’re fresh Associates and their regular team associates so no one wants to work for Walmart because other corporations pay four dollars more starting, so expect to work their job as well as yours. They use the phrase high-performing workplace which means work twice as hard for the same amount of money with a third of the people. My manager is incredibly gracious however many of the other managers I speak with, their store manager yells at them and uses vulgar language, I’ve just been fortunate in my placement. This coming from someone who was in the military. I am not leaving my manager, I’m leaving the company.

pros: Honestly, Walmart has great benefits like a college degree program, GED program, quarterly bonuses, and a fund to help employees in case of emergencies like fires. Those aspects are truly worth something because the cost to cover such things is so expensive. Pay is also pretty good.
cons: Extremely stressful and highly disorganized. Additionally, it doesn't seem as if corporate has ever really worked at the store level. They will implement new procedures for things without recognizing the harm they are doing to their own business. It becomes extremely frustrating because you as an employee can tell what is going to cause a problem immediately once new rules are sent from home office. That it turn makes employees more frustrated and tired. It also usually winds up in poor customer service.

review: There's little motivation to work hard.
pros:
- $11 starting pay.
- Once you can finally use PPTO (Protected Paid Time Off) you can use it whenever you need as long as you have enough PPTO saved up to cover the time you are out of work.
- Get weekly schedule three weeks in advance so you know when your shifts are scheduled.
cons:
- There are no raises. 
- Management tends to play favoritism when considering promotions/new job considerations rather than effort.
- Work ethic and effort doesn't matter. Some people show up and hardly do work making you do their portion of work so you don't fall behind, and they still get paid the same and you are treated the same by management.
- Most associates work with the bare minimum of effort and dedication, because there is no incentive to over achieving and going above the standard. 
- Inconsistent schedule starting out. Schedule was constantly changing within the first year at Walmart, making outside life unmanageable and tiring. Some days I'd be the "closer" working 2:00PM-11:00PM, then I'd be schedules as the "opener" working 8:00AM-5:00PM the following day, and various other shifts between. It was difficult to focus on school, family, and personal life with constantly changing shifts from week to week.

review: Good if you have limited options
pros:
The pros of working for Walmart is really getting to meet a whole variety of people customers and associates.
There are very basic opportunities for healthcare, dental, vision, life insurance etcetera if you need them.
After awhile you may get the opportunity for a set schedule.
You do get an employee discount of 10% for General merchandise and very few select groceries.
The pay starts at $11 an hour.
cons:
I'm not sure if this is just my store, but I have several cons.
The management treat you like disposable machines. The moment you're no longer useful to them or try to think for yourself, they will toss you out and replace you with some other person who will abide to their ever last waking whim. I've heard from several managers who I'm friends with who have straight told me they're instructed to treat associates poorly and not make connections with them. How do you make bonds and a healthy motivated team with people you are told not to connect with?
I mentioned benefits as a pro, but honestly if you're working for Walmart chances are you qualify for government assistance and any assistance you can get from the government will be miles better then anything Walmart has to offer. If you do want to give Walmarts benefits a try you have to jump through miles of hurdles and headaches to possibly find out you don't even qualify for their benefits. They say you qualify for benefits after a certain time, but I've been full time for a year and have worked for the company for 4 years all together and according to my HR rep I still don't qualify. Did I mention I'm diabetic? Well no mater Walmart doesn't care. If I cant afford medication they'll work me till I can't work anymore.
The discount you receive after 3 months isn't awful, but you don't even save on groceries for the most part the one thing you may really use a discount for the most. Can't feed your children oh well have 10% off this new TV.
The pay starts at $11 an hour which isn't bad or is it? Now that I think about it the Starbucks down the road pays their employees $15 an hour, Best buy makes $14, Target makes $15, McDonald's makes $13 depending on location. You know actually that $11 for all the freight, short staff, management treating you like trash, poor benefits and a discount that is actually a joke doesn't sound so appealing. Walmart should only be a placeholder if you for some reason simply can't get a job elsewhere or just need something until you can find something better.

pros:
For the right person, being a cart attendant can be pretty nice. You basically don't have to talk to anyone the whole time - just show up and push the carts. You can plug in an earbud (but not two because you gotta be able to hear your environment) and do your thing without being bothered.

You will be working outside the entire time as well, regardless of if its cold or hot or rainy. If you don't mind being cold, wet, or sweaty and want to be able to largely be left alone during your job, you might like it.
cons:
Pay isn't great, but it's serviceable - the biggest issues I ran into were that sometimes they expect a lot from you - like expecting you to have the entire parking lot cleared out by the end of a much busier-than-average night when you're by yourself.

Other big issue is that the attendance policy is extremely strict across the board. Don't get me wrong, I understand why to an extent - but it's still far too strict compared to other stores I've worked at. If you miss more than 4 days within 6 months, you're fired with no real recourse.

There's practically no communication between shifts. If you enjoy being constantly pressured and stressed, then this is the job for you!

cons: Dysfunctional, drama filled hot mess! Overnight managers are unorganized. They will put you in one area at first… be expected to finish your job and then bounce you around other departments to help lazy coworkers finish. Some nights we wouldn’t have enough people to finish. Feel pressured to stay over the 9 plus hours to finish. Never showed any appreciation. Managers talked crap about other employees and managers. Just gross. Oh expect to lift heavy boxes and pallets by yourself. How can I lift a “team lift” box alone? Please explain that to me. The best part about the job was the pay and the hour lunch. Luckily at my store they allowed you to leave. I’d never sit in the break room with those two faced lazy people.

review: Work Here If You Are Looking for Stress

Consistent pay and typically fair.
Always open so you can always work.
High turn over so if you're good you will stand out.

Zero concept of team work.
As a team lead, you have to run the whole store because all the other team leads won't follow their schedule and can get away with anything.
Coaches are almost useless, they walk around on their phones all day and have you run the whole store.
Customers can be a pain.

No real room for advancement, if you do you will inevitably step down because they recently cut management in half and expect even more out of them. They just keep cutting jobs and adding more work.

pros:
-Full-time for the most part, until someone gets too much overtime and then everyone's hours gets cut to make up for it
-Insurance and other benefits if you get it in time, You can only sign up within the first 90 days of working there and then you have to wait until October
-Vests with big pockets
cons:
- Corporate does not give a DAMN about you
- There is rarely any equipment to use (that actually works). Handhelds and printers are hard to get a hold of, and you usually have to steal the from other departments (My own manager has told me to do this on several occasions)
-Unprofessional and inconsiderate management (in certain situations). They will promote ANYONE, even ones who treat you like a child in front of associates and coworkers, show blatant favoritism, handle situations that should be in private out in the open, and share your personal information as gossip between each other and your coworkers. This is not every manager, but it is easy for them to become like this and they go unchecked by corporate as long as they produce good numbers.
-In my particular store, I have worked there for the past 5 months, and the air conditioning has never been fixed in the hardware department. It is hot as sin over there and they have to stock heavy sporting equipment in that heat.

pros:
The pay was awesome, but not worth the headache of the job position.
Having a set schedule is a really good benefit, but they do make changes and unless you have the schedule app on your phone, you won't get the notification of the schedule change.
cons:
Management! They are not willing to help you, but expect you to drop what you are doing to do one of their side chores. They do not communicate with everyone in the department, certain associates were favored while others were dismissed and not kept informed of changes taking place. Very little positive feed back, always what you are doing wrong with no explanation of why or what is being done wrong. Also, certain associates were not corrected when they were doing something wrong and it was pointed out physically or with pictures. Always will have to clean up and pick up the slack for the lazy associates and those that felt they didn't have to do their job completely, as other associates were made to finish their job. 

Always understaffed, in which makes those that come to work more stressed out and are expected to get the jobs of 4 people done... still no help from management! 

People lead needs replaced, incompetent and has been for years.

Having "mandatory" 6 days a week during back to school time (without asking the associate if they want to work the 6th day), they just schedule you.

Store manager is an issue in this store as well, never has anything positive to say to team leads. Takes the chain of command way to serious... won't speak to associates, will wait until he sees or will send a message to the team lead to relay the message about the associate, instead of asking or telling them what the issue is... has no team building moral skills at all.

Favoritism is rabid in this store as well.

You never have the necessary equipment to do the job properly and somehow this is the associates fault, despite management knowing that this is a major issue and refuse to fix it...

pros: If you like dealing with the public and talking this is the perfect entry-level job for you. Also, has its perks when dealing with the technological aspects because the handheld device that is used to shop and dispense the orders is an android and is app based, so if you are looking to go into mobile app development or like to teach people how to use the apps this is a start. The hours are usually consistent and there are a lot of benefits for part-time and full-time associates, such as education $1 a day to take classes online and potentially receive a certificate or degree in the enrolled program, medical insurance, and employee stock. Paid time off and Leave of Absence is also available.
cons: Overwhelming and stressful environment due to the amount of orders, items to be shopped, and pace. Oftentimes, the online department finds itself short staffed, usually due to call-outs, but sometimes not enough people scheduled. It is a very physically demanding job for example lifting large cases of water, barbecue grills, and trampolines. You are on your feet the whole time and there seems to be a lack of communication oftentimes, either because there are not enough employees available at the time of the issue or the fact that there is no manager in the department for the closing shift, so have to track down managers from other departments. Also, sometimes there seems to be no sense of urgency from management when dealing with a customer issue on an order.

review: Good or Bad - depends on leadership
pros: Virtually endless opportunities are available at Walmart. If you feel yourself getting bored or stagnate, talk to your supervisor or look at the internal job postings for the opportunity you would enjoy or the next step in your career.
cons:
Walmart has good and bad managers. My suggestion when looking for a new position or an internal transfer, ask questions in the interview(s) to ensure the position is a good fit for you. Remember that interviews are not only for the company/hiring manager to determine if they want you on their team; Interviews are also to help you determine if you want to work for that company and manager.
Walmart does have a rich history of culture. It has seemed that they are losing the culture over the last few years, most likely due to all the acquisitions and management turnover. I think the biggest loss they are experiencing is a core principle Sam Walton had. He did NOT want to be the biggest retailer, he wanted to be the BEST retailer. He wanted to do this by:
- Selling quality merchandise at a great price.
- Taking care of the store Associates, so they would naturally take great care of the Walmart customers.

review: Walmart Pharmacy is mediocre at best
pros:
Competitive pay with decent bonus structure
Benefits
401k 100% match up to 6%
30 minute lunch break where the pharmacy closes down completely
Paid paternity leave for 6 weeks and maternity leave for 4 months
cons:
Like any other retail chain, lack of help
Long hours (10+ hours per shift)
Inflexible schedules unless part-time
Dealing with ungrateful customers all day every day
Phones ringing non stop
Drive-thru is overbearing
Open all holidays except for thanksgiving and Christmas
Clientele is on the lower income and lower education side
No benefit of going above and beyond, just a pat on the back
No room for growth in South Florida area (need to move to another part of the state if you want to move up)
It's all about the numbers, no time for proper patient care and clinical services
Bonus is not solely based on own performance but tied together with the rest of the store.
Company always tries to find a way to make it harder to obtain max bonus (expectations changes yearly)

review: If you want to work as a Cashier, stand up for yourself and don't be someone who can be overwhelmed easily
pros: Good pay, Hours are okay, a little all over the place. There were good people, not everyone was bad. I thank them for what they could do for me, but everyone as a whole didn't care.
cons: I don't know what to write about for the cons, so I'm just gonna tell you my experience. I got left alone on day 1 for the last 2 hours of my shift. My trainer clocked out because it was the end of her shift (not her fault). Her replacement just left and told me she would be around the corner, left from there too. I couldn't get help, I had to go wandering to find it. I had to ask a lady every time what to do, which wasn't her job, but she had the answers so she helped me. I asked for a transfer because I didn't want to work in that environment and I KNOW they have positions in almost every other department. I was told there weren't any positions I "would be happy with", I wanted anything else. They also told me there were no backend positions, my roommate works in cap-2 (back end, unloading trucks), he told me there were positions open in cap-2. She then went on to say that this was the job I was hired for because the position was open. I quit because I don't want to work for a company that doesn't care their employee is crying on her breaks and literally couldn't handle the stress of trying to learn a whole job by themselves. I'll make sure I know what I'm getting into next time before I do.

pros: You get a discount card after 90 days of working. They offer college for $1 a day. Flexible hours (at least where I am currently working), and for the effort required for the job, the pay is nice.
cons: Some customers can be complete morons. If you hear a cashier say something about a customer, you can probably believe them. We see a lot, like people attempting to walk out of the doors with $500 merchandise after paying for a candy bar. We have signs on our machines in big red letters to make it identifyable when a machine will not accept cash . . . but SO MANY customers are oblivious to the point where they don't even realize until they go to pay! Some people you will want to look at and just laugh at hysterically, and some you will want to B-slap . . . but honestly, overall the pros outweigh the cons in my opinion.

pros: the pay is alright but could be better

pros: Easy flexible great management paid time off

pros: You are constantly moving, so you will get tons of exercise.
cons:
Walmart was already a pretty thankless place to work, but now it is even worse. The new management structure means no person is held responsible but the lowest ones on the totem pole (i.e. stockers). You will get blamed for things out of your control. If you attempt to fix any of the glaringly obvious problems you will be told you are the most insignificant person in the store and your only job is to open boxes to put on the shelf. 
The pay is decent for the area, but it honestly doesn't outweigh the stress of having to meet times for putting freight out. It also doesn't outweigh the strain put on your body from bending, lifting, and walking on hard concrete floors every night. 
Also, the stores get very hot at night during the summer/cold during the winter so be prepared to sweat profusely or freeze. 

Benefits are alright, but not the greatest. For a family of 3, look to pay approximately $200 per check for the cheapest insurance plan offered. The 10% discount you receive as an employee doesn't count towards most grocery items except during Christmas. You accrue sick and vacation days at a ridiculously slow rate. Which if you do use your sick days following the proper channels and policys, expect to be taken into the office and threatened with a disciplinary write up for failing to provide proper customer service since they are unable to do it for the actual reason. 
In fact, expect that to be the go to reason for any kind of write up if you haven't done anything wrong but management wants to retaliate because you called in or pointed out issues everyone wants to ignore within the store.

review: Managers are groomed to act like scociopaths
pros:
-Pay is higher than you'd expect if you have little commitments. 
-If you work in a high need area it's easy to be moved to full time compared to other jobs I've had.
cons:
-Management is where this company falls apart. The job itself is easy, but you'd be inundated with fires that management makes up to be put out opposed to hard issues that undermine the operation of the facility. 
-All power is taken away at the local level so the management has to make up things to do to justify their positions.
-The work you do is constantly undermined, and when given an impossible and contradictory task list, your work ethic is questioned when it's not completed.

pros: Management was always very friendly.
cons:
While management was nice, you'd have a hard time finding any members of management near you. There was absolutely NO formal training, and it was near impossible to ask for help or assistance. Crew members were often just as clueless when it came to knowledge of their position.

Additionally, COVID-19 safety precautions were loosely followed in the backrooms and workers would often gather in large groups with very little room in between them. My mother works in the nursing field, and it's critically important that both of us practice proper safety precautions, as I could potentially spread COVID to a customer or coworker, and she could potentially spread it to a patient or another nurse.

-endless work (it doesn't matter how much you work, it never ends, and it's never good enough. It doesn't matter if you clean the whole deli including drains and trashcans, they'll get you for the smallesr things ex. A smudge on the slicer. 
- They'll always threaten to write you up and say they won't because they're a good person

pros: My coworkers were mostly very hardworking, decent and honest types who I would often speak highly of even though they, like me, were paid the bare minimum.
cons: Coroporate atmosphere is nothing to be desired, some managers seem like they are literally out to get you for no other reason than boredom as the tour the aisles, and would often engage in 20 minute conversations on the sales floor with colleagues while everyone else worked around them. It's a very contradictory work environment, at least when I worked there. I would not go back if i didn't have to, and even if that were the case, I would make sure to not be employed there for more than a few months to a year.

pros: Walmart is a pretty good place to work, there are lots of benefits and opportunities that branch from being an associate, and the 10% discount card is a big plus! They have no problem giving you all the hours you need, plus however much overtime you could/would want. All the managers, including the store manager, treat you with respect and work alongside you to accomplish different tasks. There are opportunities for full-time associates to invest in stock in the company, put money towards a 401(K). Also health and dental can be deducted from your pay.
cons: There are some downsides to working here as well, for example, no matter where you work in the store, they will always pull you to other areas that are in other departments than your own, doing a job that you didn’t apply for. I have pushed carts, operated register, sold hunting/fishing licenses, mixed paint, and unloaded freight in several departments that aren’t my own, even when I have important tasks at hand in my own department. Also, I have heard and witnessed that the managers play favorites with certain employees, and let those certain employees get away with things that would they would fire someone that they dislike for. Certain employees are held to a different standard of labor and productivity than others.

review: Up above do not give me an option. I started working there in 2001.
pros: They have medical benefits, dental benefits, stock options, a certain amount of money each year to go towards optical and the 401K the best thing about the 401K is they match you a dollar for dollar. The department I worked in was the food department I wasn't just a good worker I was a great worker. So because of that the store manager gave me free reign for my department. The best thing about that was dealing with all of the vendors. I learned a lot dealing with all the different vendors from Coca-Cola to Nabisco and everything in between. All the decisions started with me and stopped with me. I was able to learn a lot doing it that way. If s potato chips wanted to do a super bowl display the vendor would come to me tell me what he wanted to do how big of a display he wanted to make and then it was my decision on where to put it where it would get the most foot traffic and the most eyeballs seeing the display and to make sure the spot I decided to put it in would maximize their sales. With the store manager allowing me to do that I was able to learn so much. I had to talk with all the vendors I learned how to wheel and deal with them. It also taught me how important displaying a product in the correct place really is for that products sales. One other thing they do about 95% of their promoting within the company. When I worked there I just happened to get very lucky and had a fantastic store manager.
cons: I don't even know where to start or what to say. And the only thing I can say is besides the pros I listed above everything else about the company is negative. The pay is very low. They want you to work and care about your work as if you're getting paid $100,000 a year. THE BEST WAY FOR ME TO SAY THIS IS THE COMPANY IS HORRIBLE.

cons: Can't change job codes easily, unless there is someone to replace your current position, typically. No merit raises or incentives to work hard other than one's own motivations to do good at their job. Minimal yearly raises, if meet expectations. Large turnaround, and lack of staffing. Some communication issues.

pros: It's an easy relaxing job, and pretty good for exercise especially when dispensing. It can be a fast paced job, and wearing headphones while working is a pretty nice privilege.
cons:
Honestly, there weren't any cons when I worked at a different Walmart that had OGP. The people there were great, and I miss them greatly. 

 But there are some Walmart's that WILL NOT make you happy. Sometimes to the point of a depression that affects relationships, honestly. 
So my cons are: Sometimes there are REALLY incompetent people, the ones that are lazy. Days can get really busy and stressful to the point where you're running around so much you don't have time to even catch your breath. Express runs are pretty stressful too. And the amount of times I have seen mold in some produce and groceries, and the amount of dented cans... It's a little aggravating.

pros: Good pay once you become a salaried member of management with bonus based on performance metrics

pros: It's a pretty stable job, no matter where you are. The pay and benefits are better than average. I worked there about two and a half years in two different positions before I got promoted. My coworker only worked there six months before doing so.
cons: Even though it's pretty stable, sometimes they try to phase out different positions (like when they restructured management, or got rid of all cashier registers on front end). But usually they'll just have you move to a different department, reapply, or transfer to a nearby store, worst case scenario. The pay and benefits arent great compared to Walmart's biggest competitors, Costco and Amazon. My biggest gripe is that the company is extremely anti-Union. Not like there's propaganda, but your store might be shut down if it starts one.

review: Great company with room for growth.
pros: Senior leadership and faculty goals.
cons: Training is hard to come by.

pros: Pay is only good if you are in management.
cons: Favoritism is a huge problem with this company. If you are not apart of the “in crowd” you will not move up, regardless of how well you preform. Management is unethical, they pretend or try to make it look like they follow proper protocol. When I’m reality they do not. They will notify associates that they want to hire that they have the job, while they are still interviewing other candidates. I’ve seen them go as far as pushing the hiring process out to wait for a corrective action to fall off, for an associate they wanted to promote.

pros: Great pay, great values and beliefs, great benefits, and some managers that give their employees credit, and care.
cons: Constant changes to policies, Associates that don’t pull their own weight, and some managers are on a power trip, big wigs come in and start a line of stress down the chain of command! It doesn’t matter how good you are at your job, if wal-mart home office considers your job unnecessary you will be demoted or let go. Lack of staffing that pulls their weight, mostly, because home office keeps demoting and firing the good people. There is no set schedule, so you can’t plan your life around work! You struggle to find a sleep pattern, because of the swapping back and forth between all the different work hours! In the end, though it’s a job, and it was never meant to be convenient for you, and most of the cons I listed is because wal-mart is a corporation, but if wal-mart wasn’t a corporation pay wouldn’t be that great. I don’t think a JOB could get much better than wal-mart.

review: If you are just starting to work you can work here for experience not to make a career
pros:
-You get one 15min break if you work more than 5 hours and 2 breaks if you work 8 hours.
-You can get a quarterly bonus if you work enough hours 
-Their COVID-19 policy was actually pretty decent
-They pay the most in my area
-They offer education tuition
cons:
- Don’t get pay holidays
-To get PTO you have to be in the company full time or if you are part time you have to wait like almost 2 years to get any actual time. 
-Most of the time they don’t have enough people to complete a department  
-Management doesn’t listen to you 
-A lot of work for what feels like not enough pay 
-You are expected to do everything and cover in different areas if you do learn how to do it 
-Employees are not valued or listen to 
-No benefits if you are part-time

review: Solid Experience, Step-Child like Feeling from Corporate
pros: Within our own environment (as a subsidiary of Walmart), we had a great culture and great people. Folks really cared about the look of our site and Walmart.com, and put a lot of effort in to drive both top and bottom line growth. I had positive experiences with almost everyone I directly interacted with at our subsidiary company.
cons: While working for a subsidiary of Walmart, we often felt less respected than the folks working out of San Bruno or Hoboken. However, we often felt we had much more on our plate than these other locations considering we needed to be concerned with Walmart.com and our subsidiary site. Corporate also did not do a good job at filling job positions that were left open after departures, which often led to teams getting spread extremely thin. I personally had terrible experiences with the leader of our division at Walmart.com, who was also technically in charge of our subsidiary company along with our CEO.

review: Well... It's Walmart. What are you going to do about it?
pros:
1. Their so short staffed (at mines at least) that you can pick up a bunch of hours.
2. Few CMSs cares (but they plan on retiring there)
cons:
1. Management sucks.
2. Cashier job is an odd job. (Especially now with the self- checkouts)
3. When they know your a good worker they'll run you dry. 
4. You'll be doing zoning (straitening up rows or even idles!) 
5. You're half stocker ( You don't get the pay though) 
6. You'll be doing returns ( And when working at Walmart (a large retail store) and on holidays, good luck)
7. Don't want to hire greeters, they'll use you! (Mostly if your young or too old)
8. Got more to say but don't want to waste my breath...

review: Place to start your career. Try not staying longer. If possible, choose any company over this.
pros:
- Lot to learn
