- Conversations with the right people and connections with the right people can make your career! 
- There is no other company better than this when it comes to work-life balance.
cons:
- Your talent is in no way in correlation to your career or incentive growth.
- At least 2/5times you will feel like you are being used at 1% of your potential.
- So many reorgs, if you are a man with self -esteem, it will hurt you like hell!

review: Overall a pretty decent company to work for
pros: Benefits are very good. Things like 401k, stock purchase program, healthcare, discounts etc.
cons: Sometimes can be very demanding

pros:
*Fast paced (The day goes by so quick!!)
*3 breaks - 1hr lunch, 2 paid 15-minute breaks as well!!
*The pay!! Make as much at a warehouse for half the work(but still a lot of work)
*My coworkers are amazing at my location, always willing to help
*PLENTY of overtime available if wanted, but not required!!
*They promote within which is really great.
cons:
*Management as always, but it isn’t necessarily their fault we’re short staffed in my department. This job is very physically demanding, you are moving around the whole store for all eight hours of your shift. A lot of people can’t handle it.
*Only get one weekend day off. That’s to be expected with this job however, weekends are the busiest days and you’re needed the most.
*At the time of this review I’m still in my first week, my feet & legs are SO SORE. However, I’m going from doing nothing but sitting at home for 3 months (thanks COVID), to working 40 hours a week constantly running around.
*I don’t like that they let everyone know “it’s easy to get promoted”. It isn’t easy, you have to work hard and show up, but more importantly they do play a lot of favorites there. If you’re close with the managers and do well, you will get promoted. But you have to know the right people.
*Some managers I don’t listen to you. And I get it, they’re very busy and constantly working, doing jobs that associates like myself can’t do. But I wish, if they weren’t going to do what they say they will, they would at least maybe have you write down your information so they can look at it later.

Very gracious PTO policy (6 weeks of PTO for me—10 years with company), good amount of tech hours available, pay is good
cons: Lots of “needs to dos” with short-turn around times and little direction, constantly shrinking pharmacist hours, always busy, stressful, store management treats pharmacy like a step-child even though we have to depend on them for very essential task. Transferring is very hard to do if it’s under a diff district manager and almost impossible to step down from PIC to staff position and expect a large pay cut.

review: Hectic, but often fun retail job.
pros: Walmart is an employer that has a very diverse (even in less-diverse cities) employee roster. People that work there are often representative of many countries, cultures, backgrounds, and ethnicities. Overall, this means that there's a wide variety of experiences, interests, and ideas represented by one's co-workers.
cons: Over the past years, some of the transition to a new hierarchical structure left a lot of people in the middle-ranks confused as to what was expected of them.

Management failed to see any benefits other than cutting headcount and writing the project as a success. everyone is looking for their "moonshot project" and name recognition so they can get their name noticed and get a promotion/bonus. So this place is full of half-done projects and initiatives with unrealized potential. I was headhunted out of a job to join the latest shiny projects but in a span of 2.5 years our whole org was deemed unnecessary.

review: Does not care about their employees
pros: Customers were very nice and considerate
cons:
When i became sick there was no help from managment. When costumers complained about how i looked they sent me off to stock, where i threw up in teh isle and even than they wouldnt let me go home. I had one supervisor ask if i was pregnant! I was not. A fellow employee broke her foot and even had a doctors note to prove it. Walmart "doesnt take doctor notes" This person was not allowed to sit or have any stool to help with herbroken foot. The customers werfe enraged by our treatment but managment simply hide her away in stocking until she quit from their abuse. Finally I was forced to quiet as I was sick and again WALMART DOESNT TAKE DOCTORS NOTES.
Overall managment doesngt care about the workers and nobody stays long.

review: Lack of Teamwork, Under-staffing Issues, More tenured workers seem favored
pros: Good pay in deli/ bakery, fast paced and too much to do in too little time so time goes by fast! I like the work and like being on my feet
cons: The lack of a team lead or manager on duty contributes to more tenured and more "aggressive" employees pushing around their weight and trying to manage others; there is a lack of teamwork. Management does not make a plan or follow through with issues brought to their attention, and more tenured employees seem to be favored when there is any sort of disagreement among coworkers. There is constant arguing and strife in the workplace among coworkers. There is a continual under staffing issue that causes frustration and more arguing when things get stressful, unmanageable and unreasonable with duties required to be completed within the set time frame without going into overtime.

pros: decent benefits, easy to get promoted, transferability.
cons: If you are a hard worker, they will work you to death. If you are a lazy worker, you will never promote, but probably wont get fired either. Salary management quickly forgets what it's like to be an associate. Example: I work very hard and most of the time it's only me and a few salary managers in total. Some days I need an extra 10 min on lunch to recharge and destress. They have no issues threatening a write up over 10 min over on lunch, but will turn a blind eye to associates that do nothing but walk around and talk all day! When covid hit last year walmart corporate removed attendance points for absences if you felt you needed to stay home, you could, but at the store level they were coaching associates for production, because they were calling in due to covid! I refused to write up any of my associates for this, but there were plenty that got coached and some that got terminated.

Welcom to Walmart for new employees every manager had their act they would do to say why Walmart is awesome but its well knows and often talked about that all of those stories are lies.

review: It's not bad but there's too much favoritism
pros: You learn a lot. And you will meet amazing people. The pay is good. Benefits are good.
cons: There's too much favoritism. You'll never see yourself getting anywhere then the position you were hired for. They never want to hire new associates when your short staffed( which is everyday). They're more worried about OGP than the cashiers. You deal with a lot of angry people all day. They say the more you know the higher the pay, which isn't true. If they know that you know more in different departments they will use you a lot and you'll still get your normal pay. Cashier's only get 11 an hour but every other departments minimum wage has gone up which is unfair to the cashiers and customer service associates.

pros: The hours were flexible. Management at my store was very nice and professional. The associates were also, on the balance, good to work with.

review: Bridge the Gap!  More for Less every year.  No Loyalty to long term associates
pros: Pay is good at Walmart.
cons:
-Target for bonus plans are set super stretch goals and always moving even after the year has started. 
-Long term associates displaced in every role on a regular basis. No security working for this company.
-HR doesn't work with operators of the stores. Almost impossible to find talent as its all leaving Walmart for a company with a better culture. 
-Work life balance is terrible. Store managers strongly suggested to always skip days off and forfeit vacations. PTO is very hard to use. 
-Executives manage by metrics only and don't visit stores with a support mentality (High performance culture, LOL)
-All levels managed by fear. The leaders are all fleeing.

review: Walmart sign shop was a great place to work. I thought I would retire from there

cons: Because of restructuring Walmarts shut down the sign shop completely

pros:

review: Dynamic Company, but may be a few steps behind
pros:
Good pay, culture and benefits. Believe in career growth and transparency for the most part.

For the most part believe in work life balance and management is approachable
cons:
Feels to be a few steps behind than competitors, but always trying to keep up and can do so due to financial backing.

Transparency is somewhat lacking among levels, would prefer to leave people out of meetings than add them despite associates needed to be in them to learn. Strategy could be better and more often communicated

Pivot and reorganize often which means layoffs are a potential opportunity if you are in an unlucky position. Been through 4 in only 3 years. They are moving fast to try to keep up and their move to omnichannel has led to many job displacements

pros: The pay is great for mostly easy work. I’m a senior in high school and average around $500 every two weeks, making $12 an hour (for context).
cons: At my store, at least (although I’ve heard this from countless other people working in different cities/states), masks aren’t enforced. They do nothing to protect us, even the managers wear they’re masks wrong or not at all. I’m 18 now, but you have to be 17 to be a cashier, which is when I was hired, and the managers take forever to come scan the alcohol. We used to have CSM’s (Customer Service Managers?) and there would be around 2-3 at all times. However, they demoted them and we have team leaders, and there’s only one at a time. They run the entire store essentially and are hard to find. Also, it is very easy to get fired, the points system is a joke. Customers are extremely rude and management does nothing to help you. In the event you react, you get in trouble. They change schedules after they’re made and if you don’t show up, you get a point. DISCLAIMER: it may be better as a stocker, etc but I cannot speak for them. Not worth it, looking for a new job at the moment.

pros: Unloading trucks was good exercise, you acquired adequate experience in working with tight-knit teams, and some shifts were exciting in an enjoyable backroom/warehouse environment. I learned some good safety practices, OSHA guidelines, and met some good people.
cons: Online training does little to nothing to prepare you for job. After six hours of videos they just throw you in the back and make you unload thousands of boxes of inventory. There are correct ways to unload, down-stack, and stack pallets and most times it is a cluster of different methods, safety techniques, and timings. Some days you move slow, some too fast, others have no organization.

review: Not recommend unless you enjoy consistent high levels of stress and pressure
pros: Compensation can be good but you will have to dedicate long hours, nights, weekends and holidays in order to maintain your salary.
cons:
The upper level management does not respect your time off. You will receive calls from your boss and corporate at all times including vacation if you decide to be a salary manager. 
Be prepared to work 12 to 15 hours a day 6 days a week. Nights, weekends and all holidays. In other words you may never see your family. I made the mistake and missed out on 13 years of holidays and family time. 
The company continues to replace employees with technology so basically your staff gets smaller and smaller each year while sales and profit grow.

They expect an associate from one area of the store to be able to do absolutely everything else in the entire store. They refuse to hire enough people to manage the workload and intentionally keep the store short staffed. Assistant managers (Coach's now) no longer do anything other than sit in the office and complain. The store managers are actively encouraged to be toxic and abusive. If they find out I left this review, they will probably fire me.

pros:
- 10% discount [on everything except food, because this multi-million dollar company would rather have ten houses and let their employees collect food stamps.]
- Great for people without critical thinking or usage of more than 2% of their brain.
cons:
- Extreme lack of teamwork.
- Zero accountability on people who just show up to collect a check. 
- Overworking yourself for a 2% salary increase upon review, unlike actual performance-based raises they used to offer.
- Decreased standards company-wide. 
- Absolutely clueless operations over the past ten years. [ZMS/IMS/Cap Teams and now GWP.] 
- "Incentives" laced with disadvantages for people who cannot comply with dedicating their entire being to Walmart.
- Company-made decisions that make every hourly worker I know, even ASMs and COs, scratch their head and say - *what are they even thinking*? 
- Will probably be an obsolete business in the next five years.

-Accountability needs to be improved a lot. Too many associates skating by when they ahould have been terminated.

review: not worth it! dont bother applying
pros: there werent any pros because the job was very unhealthy
cons: i worked as a part time employee and loved it when i first started. after awhile management started showing there true colors. we had to get permission to use the restroom and only take bathroom breaks during lunch ONLY if not you get yelled at and written up. we were literally timed coming from break (keep in mind its a big store and approx. 20 employees that work the night shift) so imagine how long it takes to clock in using ONE TIME clock! they treated us like slaves and expected each employee to complete an average of 5-10 palettes before our breaks if we slack while doing so we get yelled at or talked down on. I remember I was told i was going to slow to complete a palette then later then later suffered from it by having to work 7 days straight with only 1 off day. I eventually got tired of it and just quit. I dont recommend this job to anyone. The pay sucks too and its only $12.80.

pros: You get a crash course if what it means to be a HR representative for a major corporation. The pay is wonderful and the benefits are good. We are not salary so when you are off you are not disturbed. You know your schedule three week ahead of time. You are still an important part of running and growing the business. You aren’t chained to a desk/cubical. You are running around to ensure all of your employees are getting the proper attention they deserve and their voices are being heard.
cons: The balance between doing your job and allowing what the business needs to grow is tough. You are a neutral island so you can work well with your team, but can’t really trust anyone. Nothing is more important that your objectivity. You will consistently be hated for doing your job.

Management don’t communicate and not on top of things until last minute when store manager yells at them. Now you have a 5 hours to finish 6 pallets.

pros: Competitive pay, bonuses, wfh, in office snacks
cons:
To preface, I was hired as a Jet employee around the time of their acquisition by walmart. Ever hear the tale of the frog and boiling water? This is the best analogy I can make. 
After walmart took over the culture, insurance benefits, valuing of employees, and overall leadership had gone slowly downhill. 
Things had gotten so bad that my department had last more employees last year than they had in the prev 2 years combined. Upper management refused to listen to employees on suggestions that would overall benefit employees as well as improve quality of work.

Co-workers have very bad work ethic (it's Walmart and half of them are either teenagers or about to retire)

Made workers buy their own hand sanitizer at the beginning of the pandemic, didn't clean down cashier stations, and overall terrible initial reaction to COVID.

Internal website clearly calls us "servants". Exploitation to the fullest. Noone working here is happy. Managers complain when you need the bathroom. If your not busy, they make you do other people's jobs. Can't talk to co-workers. The list is endless...

Unfortunately Store Managers have become invincible in many areas and are then allowed to get away with poor leadership. From playing favorites, to failing to plan correctly and communicate correctly .. some Store Managers got there by making a good impression early on in their careers, but once they got to Store Manager - they want to "stick" it to those under them and create a confusing and disorganized work environment.

review: Decent company that just needs to change a few things.
pros: The pay is much better than working most other jobs, even better than some jobs you need degrees for. Tons of opportunities for advancement which leads to bigger pay increases. Some pretty awesome supervisors and managers. Will work with your schedule if you’re in school need a set schedule and it’s really easy to pick up extra days on short notice if you’re not already full time. Nothing is ever really bad enough to not consider working for this company when you consider how many horrible paying jobs with more responsibilities and more stress are out there. I have worked for this company on 2 separate occasions and had to leave for medical reasons both times or I would still be there.
cons: Ridiculously crazy work schedules during thanksgiving week. No holidays off. No excused absences no matter how sick you get. Some managers are absolutely horrible. Never enough workers in each department so you’re overloaded with work.

pros:
- Friendly and very helpful staff. Most customers were friendly as well.

- Could have a different food bar after x number of days of no injuries. Food we got then was pretty good too.

- Ability to work plenty of hours.

- I feel like $11 per hour was decent for a starter job. Working here 3+ years definitely helped me get through college.

- Flexible schedules. I was able to work mostly 9 AM - 6 PM schedules, which made each week's schedule easier to memorize.

- Could request time off, which was almost always approved. Never missed the Summer air show or the chance to visit my aging grandparents during my time here.

- Decent amount of work to do. Varies by dept, but mine (toys) was generally busy.

- Occasionally helping out other departments also helped diversify the work I did.

- Long one hour lunch break.

- We had a Nintendo Switch in our break room. Didn't use it much, but it was a fun alternative to browsing my phone during breaks.
cons:
- Some days the work was repetitive and days were slow.

- The occasional rude or prank-call customer. Just need to move on and go about your day like any other retail job, but still was an annoyance when it happened.

- Could not request time off on holidays. Had to plan family gatherings around the job. Not a huge problem, but rather a minor annoyance.

pros: There are no pros here
cons: No work like balance, god forbid you have children to take care of at any point in time especially if you are salary. Do not value their employees. Treat people who have been like there for 15+ years like garbage and constantly try to push them out to make room for younger, newer associates they can pay less. Benefits are garbage. Will push promotions on you so they don’t have to pay you overtime for doing 4x the amount of work you were doing before. Constantly changing the way things are done without dealing with any issues from previous changes. Upper management takes zero responsibility for anything, unless they are trying to take credit for work other people did. Always passing the buck. Worked for countless sexist managers. Was once passed up for a promotion because and I quote “your going on maternity leave so you won’t be here during peak season” ...just over all an awful experience and I worked there for well over 10 years!

$12/hr (for me at least)

If you take advantage of breaks and stuff they will fire you. 
The point system is cool but your better off only using protected PTO.
If you dont have 0 points you lose your charm.

Not a good place to make friends or get into gossip.

pros: A degree of freedom where you're not secluded to working at the same location.
cons:
The experience working at Walmart, despite some of the core values they hold dear, relies too heavily on management. General enjoyment coming into a shift comes down to the philosophies of general management. Work can either be extremely intense or at times extremely boring. Feels like a lot of time is wasted doing pointless tasks where at times you feel your contributions mean nothing
 
Another con includes the way scheduling is done. It takes 3 weeks to change your availability and to go on leave. Scheduling at times does not agree with your stated availability and it's too hectic to change it. Work/life balance becomes difficult to maintain on top of the extreme changes in scheduling

review: Could have been better with care toward associates.
pros: Repetitive work, scanning backroom for items that needed to go out to the floor, and running carts, sometimes you’d get set in different departments but it’d only take a few shifts to learn and was overall pretty nice work, but the cons outweighed the ease/steadiness of the job. Hours worked was pretty consistent (40-hour work weeks) but the days you were scheduled for were not (shifting schedules around happened a lot, and they often didn’t care about how many days it’d leave you working in a row...). If you were fulltime, you were eligible for health insurance coverage. Regardless if you were fulltime or parttime, you got a discount card for 10% that you can use in the store, and the pay ($11) was decent when you’re not overworked and working pretty much more than one persons job.
cons: Management/supervisors could care less about your health and schedule. Attempts to inform them that you couldn’t work a certain amount of days in a row without getting sick went through one ear and out the other. They could rework the schedules to make it so you’re working 6-7 days in a row without reprieve, have two days off, then rework it again to the same thing, which is physically and mentally draining. They also didn’t care to hire new people often enough to replenish the people that left or get fired - so you’d often work an area by yourself with an area that’s too big to work by yourself and be finished by the end of the day, and you’d basically be working two or three peoples jobs. As fun/repetitive as the work was, it wasn’t worth it when the management didn’t care about your health, physical AND mental.

review: Like all jobs it has its pros and cons.
pros: Steady work, insurance, 401k, little bonuses, you can buy stock in the company, you get the chance to move up in the company.
cons: Everything you do is never good enough in their eyes. They expect to much from one person they never hire enough people they would rather work everyone to the bone with the smallest amount of associates they can get away with. Yes you can move up in the company but they will expect you to live and breath for them and as soon as its not enough they take everything away. Everyone of the (Hourly) associates deserve so much more than what they get. Not only do they have to suffer from the bosses, on really bad days you get it almost as bad from the customers they love to just beat you into the ground Especially because they know you can't do anything because you will be fired.

pros: Great benefits and 10% employee discounts
cons: Massive lay-offs which you won't hear about on Linked In or the news. Lay- offed 600+ professional Talent, while other Tech companies are hiring, Walmart Global Tech is laying off Tech talent and Health & Wellness professional. Investing heavily OUTSIDE of US inside of keep those jobs in US. This constant stop and go of not know whether you will get a 6AM call out of the blue by your manager or VP (always last minute scheduling) which now one knows is to get "canned" and lay-off. It has caused so much PTSD and Anxiety in an already stress time in our lives with COVID-19.

pros: Company is inclusive creates a good environment at most stores they provide 401k, health benefits, and good pay.
cons: The final store I worked for has a store manager whom doesn't practice the tenants of the company has openly hazed associates doesn't create a inclusive environment refuses to leave the office spends a majority of his time on ESPN does not follow the teach train and grow standards for the company and has expectations that people who aren't trained will fully be able to exicute new programs before they roll out.

pros:
Consistent lunches and breaks
low oversight
versatile ppto and pto systems
several international communities not controlled by corporate (harder to be exploited)
A lot of very specific training., which was shown to me out of order and mostly didn't apply to my role.
cons:
Hiring managers are not the managers you'll work under, so terms of employment will be completely ignored (Why I quit)
Changes in the workplace are announced publicly before privately, and typically contain outright lies for PR reasons.
Manipulative management will attempt to have you believe you're underperforming while stocking well above targets.
Recently Walmart cut schedule distribution and department heads in half, doubling workload across the board with no pay rise.
Covid requirements not followed, management even discriminated against me for wearing a mask too often. I was also promised no customer interaction then scheduled on the floor during business hours.
Orientation is done by HR (People Lead) who are not familiar with the roles they train for. Nothing shown in orientation was actually relevant to my job, and I had to be shown around again once I was scheduled.
HR (People Leads) are incompetent and refuse to make changes requiring HR, even with the approval of my team lead, head coach, and at one point, the assistant store manager, which essentially meant I had to talk to 4-5 people to make even minor changes to my job and availability, each of which had different, ridiculous requirements.
Getting hired requires nepotism. I applied 3 times with roughly the same qualifications, but only got hired when an employee I knew recommended me to 3 different managers. I don't believe it's possible to be hired alone at Walmart using a typical, healthy method in your job search

review: Great place to work but make sure to have senior advocacy
pros: Amazing place to work. Compensation is very competitive with good benefits. Truly puts customers and associates at the center.
cons: Make sure to have exposure of your work to senior leadership. It is important for them to see the value of your work. Unfortunately, Walmart has constant reorganizations and without senior leadership support and advocacy, chances are you will not survive

pros:
I would definitely recommend working at the Walmart Home Office in Bentonville as a young professional for a few years.

Pros:
- Very affordable cost of living
- Attractive corporate benefits (Walmart store discount, stock options, WLFC, 401k match, etc.)
- Strong company culture and values (instilled by Sam Walton)
- Strong corporate leadership
- Fayetteville (University of Arkansas, Dickson Street)
cons:
I ultimately decided to leave Walmart due to the home office location in Bentonville Arkansas. As a young professional, I had a great time for my first 1-2 years in Arkansas, but without family in the area or any connection to Arkansas I was ready to broaden my horizons and explore new opportunities in a larger city with more young professionals. If I already had a family and was looking for an affordable place to settle down, I could see myself living in Bentonville.

Cons:
- Bentonville (Small town with small young professional network)
- XNA flight options and prices

I have had the opportunity to work with the company for 5 years and in these five years my skills and abilities within the workplace have increased thanks to the commitment and dedication of the administration. Some of the points that the company has helped me improve within the workplace is the way I speak, the handling of merchandise and knowing how to manage my time so that the work comes out, not only on time but effective. The company allows one as an associate to grow and aspire to a better position.
cons: Within the workplace there are many pros and cons but as long as one is looking to improve our lifestyle, fight for our goals and dreams and grow within a company, one is more aware of the pros than the cons.

review: Never had a problem so far
pros: Very flexible with my schedule. Never had a problem with it. Yearly increased salary depending on your review from 1-3% increase. So far, everything is going smoothly.

pros: The pay is great. I love making $15 an hour in my department. I also love the flexible hours of this department. They also have this great system where you can take out up to half of your paycheck before you get it, so long as you've already made that money.
cons:
Walmart has a point system. Five points and you're out. You get one point if you have to miss a shift. Doesn't matter if you're sick or your kid is sick. You get half a point if you are more than nine minutes late. Doesn't matter if there's traffic or your kid is sick. If you miss three or more days of work for being sick or something, you get no points. How does that make sense? Points go away 6 months after you get that point.
Also specific to my store, and probably some others, my management has never actually worked as associates in this department. They run it very badly because of that. Also, they definitely play favorites. We have one guy in our department that doesn't do any work and actually hinders the department and is extremely rude to everyone he doesn't like which is 80% of the department, but he is best friends with one of the managers. If we even say something against this guy, they will find a way to fire us. In fact, they have fired almost all of the competent members of our staff in the past couple of months for saying things that the managers did not like. I brought it up to the manager above them and they just tried to make me move departments. And they will lie to cover up why the people were fired.
Lastly, I have a diagnosed anxiety disorder with panic attacks, but I am on medications. The other day, I had a panic attack during work about both work and other issues. The next day, my managers confronted me, and basically told me that I can't be worrying about other things during work and I should just not have panic attacks during work because they're not paying me to do that.

pros: The only possible pro I can think of is the coworkers that I have met. This would be a good first job, but only to keep for less than a year. Anything more, and they start to take advantage of you.
cons: The pay is too low for all the work CAP-2 does. It is the hardest job, and is the lowest paid in the store, despite the fact that most of Walmart’s revenue relies on us. Cashiers are paid more than us. If you want to be appreciated and paid decently, I would suggest any other job in the store. I have worked at Walmart for two years, and not received a raise. From what I’ve heard, pretty much every Walmart treats their CAP-2 team like absolute trash. (Also our raise from last year was taken, and given to the Deli/Bakery workers, so that their pay would go from $11 to $15 per hour.) Just trust me, don’t do it.

review: Consistent Communication Issues, But Relatively Good Pay
pros: Starting pay at all Wal-mart locations not in states with higher minimum wages is $11.00/hr, so that's a plus. It's not a difficult job, and there's a good amount of schedule flexibility.
cons: Communication between management is consistently horrendous. It's entirely typical for an associate to take blame for an issue caused by poor management, or to be assigned more work than could reasonably be expected of them during their time on the clock because of poor labor management. While I personally have never dealt with this, I've seen it on multiple occasions and can only count my blessings. As a retail position, it is naturally very high stress, as is to be expected.

review: If I could give it -5 stars I would.
pros: You get a paycheck and health insurance. Hourly co workers are generally nice and hard working.
cons: Almost every aspect of the job is a con. Incompetent management that couldn't lead their way out of a paper bag, and don't make any effort to do much besides complain and hang out in the office all day. Can't motivate their employees to work properly, so they attempt to use fear to do so, instead of treating them like humans with emotions and feelings. Expect non management hourly employees to take on management roles without promotion so they can have someone else to blame for their own ineptitude. Create safety hazards to both customers and employees, but fail to address those that effect employees. Workload is ridiculous, and expectations totally unrealistic. They work good employees to the point of exhaustion, and don't train new ones so that the workload can be more evenly distributed. Pay long time employees the same as new hires, because everyone gets the same raise anytime one is actually given instead of basing it on quality of work. Home office is totally detached from how a regular store operates, and creates new systems, changes their minds, and then reverts back to essentially an old system. It's exactly what you would expect from a corporate giant such as Walmart, a total lack of empathy from the top down, and focused on ever increasing their already obscene profits at the expense of those who can't cope and burn out. This company makes you feel like you would rather die than come in for another day of emotional and physical abuse. This is that place, where hopes and dreams come to die. Look elsewhere if you want a job that's at the very least tolerable.

review: You can do this job...if you want to.
pros:
Okay. I am a reasonable person. I do not hate this job. There are a few things that I think work.

1) Teamwork. Walmart just went through a restructuring. Department managers are a thing of the past. Instead, you have team leads like myself. I oversee 5 departments. The good thing about this is that it helps to break down the walls that divided the departments before. You no longer have department managers that are territorial over their own areas and people. There are only associates within each department. Associates are much more willing to bring variety to their days by assisting in a new way.
2) Technology makes the job super easy. I never really need training on anything. Every device I pick up is as easy as a self-checkout. Nothing I've ever done was "hard."
3) Room for advancement. Walmart will take you as far as you are willing to go. Even now, I am being asked about the next level up. You just have to want it. 
4) The people. The people of Walmart have their own stereotype...but I like them. The customer service interactions are a refreshing break for me at times. I get along with my coworkers as well. I feel like we are soldiers in a war at times...and that brings out a sense of brotherhood.
5) Fast days. You work hard and go home tired.
cons:
1) No victories. The volume of a Walmart Supercenter creates a neverending wave of stock. We have what's known as the dreaded "2-truck night." It's when the warehouse is backed up and sends an extra trailer to your store. These were supposed to end at Christmas, yet here I am on January 29th telling you we had three 2-truck nights this week. It's like trying to mop up the ocean. 
2) Callouts. So, remember what I said about associates being willing to add variety to their days? The best way they have discovered to do this is to stay at home. Imagine, if you will, being the team lead overseeing 3 service areas (paint mixer, fabric cutter, and gun sales) in addition to your other departments. Now, imagine a Saturday that you are working and your ENTIRE TEAM calls in from every department you oversee. You better learn to clone yourself.
3) Morale. The reason they are calling out is because everyone hates their jobs. It is exhausting, thankless work. If you are an upbeat, positive person, you will soon learn how to keep that to yourself.
4) Customer complaints. Go ahead, admit it....you have said that Walmart is greedy because they won't hire any cashiers. You may have angrily told that to a Walmart stockboy while you were 15th in line at checkout. Now go back and read my cons. There were 6 cashiers scheduled...none of them showed up. You told off that stockboy because his coworkers laid out.
5) Micromanagement. There are multiple coaches (formerly assistant managers) in a Walmart Supercenter. If you are a hard worker that comes to work, every single one of them needs you. You are asked to do things that have nothing to do with your area by people you do not directly report to. You have to learn to say "no" to your superiors...which is a weird thing.

cons: If you have nothing else going on in your life, and your entire existence is showing up to work, then going home and watching tv/playing video games/whatever, then it will be soul-draining. Also, the higher up managers on the totem pole are completely clueless and have no idea what is going on or how anything works.

pros: If your lucky, you could have nice coworkers, who will tell you the truth about working at walmart, and they will help you develop because your Operational manager will not care to train you. There is also a big bonus but you have to suffer a year to get that.
cons:
There is no work- life balance, you work 14-17hrs a day depending on which schedule you pick. The area manager gets handed all of the assignments/projects from upper management, and on top of that you have to deal with your area manager responsibilities, while making sure you reach your goal for the day. 
When you want a vacation they will ask why? 
Do not ever accept the first offer, because you will regret it after working long hours and working on your off days when the season hits. 
Area managers have to calculate every move, get comfortable with associates always being right even when they are at fault. 
Pray that you get a "good" operational manager, or even a coworker who will train you on the job. You will be thrown in the ocean with sharks (associates) who will want to see you fail, especially when you are new to the company.
If you want to work to the top, you have to carry on more projects and there is no team at that point. Its all about making yourself good.

review: The experience and work is important but still not a career setting.
pros: Training is very thorough and prepares you for all of the basics with step by step instructions such as proper scanning, bagging, etc.. You fill out hours of availability as part of the paperwork so they know when you're comfortable working and you are also allowed to change it in the future if the need arises. The work is flexible and management does not complain if you cut corners and just bag everything by shapes to speed up your line. Also, I live only about 10 minutes from my work site and pretty often see people I know shopping that can "visit" while I'm working which makes the experience a little more special than my last job which was privately held.
cons: The job is secretly part time even though I checked off both permanent and full time on the paperwork during the open interview/ job fair period. (My job coaches had to inform me it is at least very unlikely to ever lead to full time. ) You are required to work almost every single weekend if available once you're roughly a month into the experience and can handle longer lines. You are required to work some major holidays like Thanksgiving and may be scheduled to work earlier than your hours of availability on those days.

pros: ONLY good thing about Walmart was the income and benefits - the ENTIRE job itself sucks 150,000%
cons: Get treated like crap, get forced to do about fifteen departments jobs, then yelled at for not doing your actual job - or getting sent as a cashier out to push carts only to hear management yelling about lines - well gee if 3 of your cashiers weren't having to push carts cause you didn't schedule any freaking cart pushers maybe the lines - which were probably a couple lines with 2 or 3 people in them - our upper management would FREAK out about "lines" and it'd literally be one register had three people counting the one being checked out - that isn't a line. CONSTANTLY was spending 1/2 or more of my days at least half the week or more at times, sometimes ENTIRE shifts multiple days in a row forced to push carts because they were too cheap to hire more and too lazy/scared to fire the ones who weren't doing their freaking jobs or who just no called/no showed and didn't get fired for it/afraid if they did the horrible employees would come after them claiming discrimination even though they should easily have poor attendance or video footage of them wasting hours of time on the clock etc as evidence to dispute any such claims, etc. Not to mention the god-awful customers - screw the customers - some aren't bad, heck some are amazing, but at least a quarter to half on a given day were the rudest people ever and god help you when a Karen comes through or coupon-ers with their book trying to scam the store and trick new cashiers or just people that weren't gonna be happy and will lie right in front of your to CSMs or managers about you, etc. I could go on for literally days - but as said in pros - the ONLY good things about the job was the income and affordable insurance - and the income is still TERRIBLE - working 30-35 hours a week as a part timer for 4 years I was ONLY making $11.22 - maybe making $1100-1200 a month before taxes - with a roommate and an apartment that's under $600 a month TOTAL some months I was lucky if I had $30 bucks to spare - (should have been $11.66 by my count but every time they raised the base pay any annual raises you'd earn disappeared - granted you still made more than before but the whole thing about the annual raises was that it was a TINY little something for suffering another year in that crapshow - just cause the company chooses to increase pay shouldn't take that away imo - granted that wouldn't have drastically changed anything paycheck wise but still :P. Also, did I mention that if I didn't miss ONE day of work for the ENTIRE year - wasn't sick, didn't have to call out, leave early, have anything BESIDES a death in the immediate family - since you know - Walmart doesn't count aunts, uncles, nephews, nieces, cousins, etc as immediate family, even though grandparents - same degree of separation a parents sibling versus a parents' parent - since at least you get three days of bereavement - would net me a WHOPPING six MAYBE depending on hours and all - days of PTO that I could use TOTAL. I was there over four years and didn't EVER ONCE ask for any days off because I literally couldn't afford it. Then there's the whole favoritism, racism, sexism, and blatant letting some get away with murder just about while writing others up for the TINIEST of infractions or complaints, etc that my store had.

pros:
1.) You can take your break anywhere in or outside of the store. Just don't leave the lot because the breaks are only 10-15 mins.
2.) Access W-2 Forms on computer/smartphone.
3.) Store really clean, floor super shiny, unless it's winter.
cons:
1.) You'll be relieved from duty to take break or lunch... IF YOU ARE LUCKY! Most of the time your replacement is taking a century to show up.
2.) If you have history of back pains, weak arms and legs, unable to lift 20 lbs. This isn't the job for you. Injured on site and filing for Workers Comp will result you receiving a write up and you can only have 3 max.
3.) Walmart doesn't care about their workers well-beings. Cut-throat savages!
4.) Day and Afternoon Dept./Managers are nice but if you are nights or overnights they're jerks.
5.) If you have a history of dental problems... You mightest well get your own dental insurance because Walmart insurance doesn't cover jack. Not even 6-months teeth cleaning.

Very anti-union.. they really try to convince you to be as well, with everyone you work with being anti-union. creates an environment where you don't dare to speak out and say your own opinion.

Be prepared to constantly see parents hitting, screaming at, and abusing their children, including babies, even in the lines to check out. disgusting.

pros: None. Don't work here if you have any dignity.
cons: Terrible management. They treat everyone below a Department Manager rank as disposable robots. Only managers' friends and brown nosers will ever be promoted, and that's regardless of how little they know or how new they are. The hardest working people who carried the store for over a decade can't even change shifts without begging for months on end while the manager's pals flip-flop shifts and positions - including management positions - whenever they want. It didn't used to be this way 8-10 years ago, but wow have things changed.

review: Great workout, happy CUSTOMERS and MANAGEMENT, but only IF you keep your numbers high
pros:
Didn’t finish high school? Have a degree and lost your income or job due to COVID?  Served time and are a felon? Well then, Walmart is right for you. It doesn’t matter who you are, what achievements or lack there of, old or young, man/woman or trans, can or cannot speak English and if you have a disability, Walmart will hire you and everyone starts with the same hourly pay. 
Clocking in at 4/5am and clocking out at 1/2pm allows to have every afternoon off. After 90 days, you get to use your discount card on everything EXCEPT for (see cons for detail), my department manager is a true leader, she gets her job done, helps pick, dispense,  helps in other departments and treats everyone as an individual human being instead of a number.
cons: (From discount card)- you CAN’T use it on ANY FOOD which really matters when you earn LESS than $12 an hour and work full time. After mortgage, monthly bills, prescriptions, medical, pets, car payment... your left with less than $70  to feed 2 people for a month.  Real benefits for full time associates don’t kick in until 12 months. Don’t be surprised if there is NOT any HR personal in your store for months on end. Be careful about your points, even if your out on leave... you must report your absence. If you have an idea on how things could be more productive, it doesn’t matter. Your individual associate hands on experience doesn’t earn you a voice to share an idea that would financially or productively benefit the store and company.  Best advice, keep your head down, mouth shut (unless your with a customer), do your job and go home.

review: They have really changed. They used to be about people, now they're about money
pros: Vacation policy was decent if you work there for 10 or more years. Employee discount card.
cons: Expensive insurance, if management doesn't like you they make you suffer, they keep cutting hours making it an unsafe environment for customers and employees, they allow customers to treat employees like trash and then give them a gift card for doing so and write up the employee that didn't do anything wrong. Customer service is trained to follow return policy while managers are trained to make the lesser employees look bad and return all kinds of stuff that people have the nerve to bring back. You can't get more than an average eval without district manager approval and for them to approve it you have to be a yes man. If too many customers complain about you they will fire you, even if the complaint is a lie and you can prove it. Once you start working for walmart none of your family or friends can give you any type of gift or loan if they shop at walmart or that's grounds for termination.

review: What I Know Since Being Hired April 2020

cons: Walmart used to care about its employees and customers but now it seems that its only interest is in the bottom line. An example is they are removing all of the registers in my Neighborhood Walmart in exchange for all Self Checkout. The employees at the stores are the only ones who seem to care that the customers hate the change. Walmart also just reconstructed and decided that they did not want so many CSM's and instead decided that people with less experience deserved the job more than seasoned CSM's who have been with the company for 15+ years.

pros: Competitive pay and good benefits

pros: Managers look the other way with everything. It's really hard to get fired for anything other than attendance, and even with that, you get chance after chance, especially if the managers "like" you. If you show up you can pretty much guarantee you'll be able to keep your job, unless they eliminate your job altogether. The whole chain of command is extremely corrupt and it makes it easy to get away with things like taking two-hour lunches, calling in and using personal time to do whatever you want or to come in super late, etc. Store managers tend to not notice you beyond your first month or so where they pump you up for the possibility of having a "career." This can be a pro or a con however you want to look at it. Just be aware that the only way you're actually going to move up the ladder is if you pucker up that kisser and use it every chance you get. The best way to kiss arse is to pretty much never take a day off. Or sleep with an asst manager or whatever they're called nowadays. I've seen that one work too. You get an hour lunch which is nice and two paid 15 min breaks. There are times where it's fun to work at Walmart, like when you go to the Academy for a week and they give you a gas card that you can use for whatever. Every once in a while, a cool manager comes along but quickly disappears, but while they're there you may learn different things about different departments. I found out that being properly cross-trained isn't encouraged, but when a string of people call off you'll always be asked to do their job, regardless of whether you've been trained to do that job or not, and leave your area unattended to go to s-it. The baseline philosophies of Walmart are actually something that I believed in: "One Best Way." But what it boils down to is the store managers run their stores however they choose, and I guarantee their preferences have poor Mr. Sam rolling in his grave. If you're hellbent on feeling superior, have an affinity for power trips, and aim to learn as little as possible about how the store is run, a store manager at Walmart is perfect for you. I must say you'll meet some of the sweetest ladies in the world at Walmart. They can make or break your shift, and uplift your spirit, and teach you a lot about life and help you realize there's a world outside of Walmart and it's not that serious.
cons:
The pay sucks. For example, Target starting pay is $4.00 more per hour. They eliminate positions and therefore get rid of people all the time. If you've had a coaching on your record and they just so happen to re-structure the system, 
 kiss your job goodbye. Turnover is laughably high from the bottom to the top. Because they don't ever discipline employees and give them a million chances to f-up, you can expect to habitually be overworked along with being underpaid. You'll be doing three people's jobs regularly. And if you don't know how to do their job, you'll get a thorough 5-minute training session, most likely from a manager who knows even less than you do and be thrown to the wolves. They seem to pride themselves on having up-to-date, technologically advanced equipment. But most of the time the crappy thing doesn't work, or has a dead battery, and then there's only one working and your supervisor has to steal it because they actually need it. Then they don't give it back, or leave it on a cart somewhere for another person to steal. As well, our cash recycler was a piece of utter garbage, despite being regularly cleaned and updated. It's the most frustrating thing for the employees and the customers, but has no overall effect on management, so they don't care. Another thing, Walmart is cheap and that equates to long lines, no cashiers, self-checkout only scenarios. They cut hours all the time and force people to go home if they're going to even get 20 minutes of overtime. Or they'll cut hours altogether and you'll end up with a roster of 5 people for the entire day to spread out across the entire front end. Sometimes cashiers would have to take my keys and cover my lunch because they don't schedule another manager with me like they're supposed to. I remember one day, when I was about 7 months pregnant, I stood on my feet for my entire shift- 10 hours- at the customer service desk. No breaks, no lunch. Nothing. The lines stretched to the back of the stores, and one of my morning cashiers closed her line and walked off (I am not being hyperbolic). I told her "just go" and continued to hack away at my customer service line. The petty, backstabbing politics are potent among the managers. Don't ever expect them to take your side in a disagreement or see anything from your perspective. If you receive a coaching, beware of open-dooring it. Especially if you go above the store manager's head because you're uncomfortable speaking to him. You'll have a target on your back for the rest of your time at Walmart. If you ever plan to transfer, do not make your store manager or direct supervisor aware until you've successfully mapped out a plan with the other store and spoken to that store's management. If they know you wish to transfer, they'll smile at you and wish you good luck. Then swiftly give you a "bad grade" on your evaluation, not tell you about it, and feed you some bulls-it line about how you need to work just a little harder, but you're doing okay, and please sign here. Always ask what your performance is rated at your evaluations. If you have a needs improvement rating, you can't transfer or move up. It's dangerous to work at Walmart. You'll be required to watch a video on how to get out alive if there's an active shooter. There's a reason you have to watch this training video several times a year. While I worked there, the El Paso shooting happened. There's no security at Walmarts and there were numerous bomb threats and "scares" following the tragedy in El Paso. They put a police officer at the door for about two weeks, and when everything died down they stopped paying for that, even though it greatly deterred shoplifters and general mischief. Lastly, they don't take sexual harassment seriously. I had a close friend transfer to another Walmart only to be regularly harassed by the store manager. When she reported it, corporate never so much as followed up with her. However, they did make the store manager aware, creating a volatile environment for her that resulted in her quitting. That disgusts me, and I can never respect a company that treats victims of sexual harassment (male and female) like they don't matter, and it's easier to not disrupt the daily goings-on. But, someone at corporate will take the time to be petty and give the store manager a head's up that one of his employees is accusing him of sexual harassment. Truly the trashiest, sleaziest, laziest, shadiest people I've ever associated with worked with me at Walmart. And those people were the ones who succeeded, despite numerous complaints to corporate and various confrontations with employees and even their girlfriends. I wouldn't wish a career at Walmart on my worst enemy. Ironically, one of my worst enemies, while I worked there, was the HR manager. I thank God every day they told me I couldn't come back. It was a shock and a bummer at first but what a blessing in disguise! I learned so much about myself but it was a painful, emotionally trying few years that I try so hard to look fondly upon. TL;DR: Just apply at Target.

review: My experience at Walmart DC has been filled with many pros, but also many cons.
pros: The pay is awesome. For the area I live in, it's the highest paying job around. Also, the benefits are pretty nice. You get good bonuses for good attendance, they offer Health, Dental, Vision, Life, etc., there's two different types of paid-time-off, one of which is protected. This means you don't face any consequences for sudden call ins, being late, or clocking in from lunch late, etc.
cons: It is extremely hard work in most areas. My area is even considered the easiest and I can still say I am extremely exhausted every single day. The hours are no less than 10 hours, for either 3 days a week or 4. Even working 3 days a week, if you aren't a very hard working, production-driven, dedicated to labor type of individual, this might not be the job for you.

review: Definitely Not A Long Term Job
pros:
- High pay for the area if you have no experience in anything, I literally mean nothing.
- Very fast hiring process
- Lots of overtime if you want extra pay
- Lots of choices for your schedule, weekends (3 /12 hr days) or weekdays (4/10 hr days - or 5/8 hr days) or a mix for swing shifts, this is for Full-time. Part-time would be 2 /12 hr days for weekend shift or 2.5 /10hr days for week day shift, however I dont think you can come in for overtime or get benefits if your part-time.
- You build up PTO fairly quickly after your 90 day probation period and you can use that whenever you like, regardless if your managers dont want you to, its one thing that is very worker orientated over there. When you have earned your time-off you can take it whenever you like, and thats that.
- Once you have been there a while you can switch to different positions within the DC and that can help build work-experience in other fields other than stacking boxes.
cons:
- Very strict on everything, down to the smallest detail, your not micro-managed by a person but by a automatic machine. It tracks everysingle thing you do; the tasks of your job, to using the bathroom. As in, there will be a gap in your time record and that needs to be made up or accounted for, its not uncommon to have your supervisors ask you where you where for that last 10 mins because you used the restroom. It uses time to account for every employees tasks and how efficient they are.
- There is an atomshphere of "every employee is supposed to go above and beyond and do more work than nessesary". If you do that you are treated fairly, however if you just show up for a paycheck and do your work and leave you are treated inferior, like you are not a good employee because you dont want to do extra work to make the supervisors look good. I saw a lot of this.
- Very short breaks
- A few tyrannical supervisors who get-off to dominating subordinates, the typical psychopaths
- Get fired for anything, however they dont "fire" you they just make your life miserable until you quite so you are not eligible for unemployment. Saw that a TON. The reason is because the most common job at the DC is terrible, pays well but is so brutal on your body that the turn-over rate is above 50%, its a churn-and-burn business. Take young people in, chew them up, spit them out if they cant handle it. It is what it is.

review: Good pay but the whole "Family" thing is bad and the way they treat workers
pros: 1. Everything is there : Food, drinks, medicine, snacks, tv's.
cons:
1. No PC parts.
2. They don't like free thinkers or people who recommend changes to the store.
3. They try and call each other "family" but your just an employee that does more work than the whole manager team.
4.Lazy management team, they don't care if you get injured as long as it's not a broken bone.
5. If a customer is harassing you or being racist it takes AP or Management 10min to get out of their office to help and stop the customer from harassing you.
6. Many of the Managers tempers are bad and abuse their power.
7. It's hard to become a manager unless if your friend is a manager or if you work at the same Walmart for 3+ yrs.
8. If they find out about worker unionizing they will fire you and everyone who talks about unions.
9. 10% Discount card which is useless because of the tax percentage in OH is 7% so in total you get a 3% discount on items.

pros: Is steady work with decent job protection, and surrounded by good and caring people (most of the time), does offer opportunities to grow, inspires good work ethic, offers decent health benefits, and to a degree takes care of their employees.
cons: Depending on the upper management; work can be a little taxing to tedious when it comes to perfection, and some mangers resort to verbal and emotional abusing some of their employees. ( though not many and not often) The company does have a strict ethics program to handle this but it would seem that some level of biases has slightly corrupted this over time, and as a result it can be ineffective at times. But by far the worst con that comes to my mind is sadly, the mind set of some of the people who do simply come into shop, but to verbally and emotionally abuse any employee in anyway that they can, leading up to and including threats of termination. Coworkers tend to get along but that doesn't stop them from being piety and bitter towards one another and some even go out out of their way to threaten one another employment and even go to extremes to intimidate one another if they feel that they are being challenged in anyway. If any employee feels underemployed, helpless and targeted, it is easy for them for quickly to lash out at others or take drastic actions, causing the company to enforce a very strict " no rehire" policy making it an overall unforgiving and uncaring place to work.

And management talking to customers like that too. If you want to be degraded by management and have corporate do nothing about it...or if you want the employees talking to staff and customers like that also. Really horrible environment to come in and just do your job.

review: Good short term job, bad long term job.
pros:
Can be easy to be hired on so long as you're professional in your interview.

Usually $11/h base pay so if your state has a lower minimum wage, it's a decent choice.

Flexibility with your custom schedule.

Usually schedule you 32-40h a week regardless of your employment status.
cons:
Horribly random schedule if you don't have *very strict* availability set.

They'll give you 32/40 hours a week every week while keeping you part time or even temporary which means no benefits or PTO.

Responsibilities have increased with the removal of department managers but the base pay for all associates hasn't budged past $11/h.

Some departments are understaffed and are frequently told "manpower is not an excuse" when we fail to get everything done in a day.

review: My experience with Walmart over a span of 10 years has been a good one.

cons: People will be people,and working with customers and associates is always challenging.The downside is dealing with negative attitudes and complaints which can be very taxing as with any company.The nature of the job is too get it done fast yet with making the customer feel welcome and special.Its not always very easy to accomplish.

pros: Good benefits, like paid time off, pays for most of school though Walmart U, and insurance
cons: Nobody works, it seems electronics employees have a contest to see who can do the least amount of work and it really backs up the process in which merchandise flows. It’s a very unorganized environment. Also the Walmart management doesn’t coach their bad employees or try to keep their good ones so it’s a really confusing environment. Walmart is a really greedy company. You will not feel valued until you leave but even then they will find 2 more people to replace you. It’s a very childish environment, and c’mon nobody lies on their death bed saying, I’m glad I put in all those hours at my local Walmart. While I have your attention, support your local business instead of giant retail chains who won’t even unionize or respect their workers.
